model_response: Considering that the clinical trial will be conducted to assess the effects of horizontal ridge augmentation techniques using decompression method and ridge splitting method using piezosurgery, the assessment of vertical bone loss will be conducted as a secondary outcome measure. The rationale for this is to evaluate the performance of both methods in preserving vertical dimensions of the alveolar ridge, which is another critical factor for implant success. We can assess the vertical bone loss by comparing the pre-surgical vertical bone level to the level of bone after one year of implant placement. The measures for vertical bone loss can be defined as "the distance from the implant shoulder to the crestal bone level on the panoramic radiograph."

Another important aspect to evaluate would be alveolar ridge contour. This can be captured through bone density assessment on the CT scan images [25, 34]. We can measure the bone density within the alveolar ridge before and after the intervention using a specific region of interest (ROI) template and analyzing the grayscale intensities of pixels enclosed within the template. The changes in bone density between the baseline and the follow-up CT scan images are the measure for this outcome measure . The bone density of each participant will be measured twice, and a median value for each time point will be used for analysis. Would you like to add this measure?

They rate a patient's overall degree of fulfillment on all the items of the scale on a 3-point scale: 0 (needs support), 1 (requires supervision), and 2 (can manage by own capacity). The scale will be assessed before the start of treatment as usual (TAU), before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. Using this measure will provide insights into the patient's overall functioning.

Certainly! The BSI was first introduced in 1978 and validated in 1992 by Derogatis and Melisaratos. It consists of 53 items that are rated on a 5-point Likert scale. It also includes an additional item designed to assess the perceived change in health status between the time of the survey. Using the BSI, patients can report on the following nine symptom clusters: somatization, obsession-compulsion, depression, anxiety, hostility, phobic anxiety, paranoid ideation, and anergia. The questionnaire will be administered before the CoMBI-SMI training, during the last week of TAU, and the fourth week after CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a comprehensive evaluation of changes in symptoms over time in this study.

I suggest using the Questionnaire on Quality of Life in Patients with Mental Illness (QoL-NSP). It assesses a wide range of life domains and is tailored specifically for patients with mental health conditions. It was developed in 2009 and offers a comprehensive evaluation of an individual with SMI's quality of life. The questionnaire covers topics such as the social, vocational, psychological, and family domains, providing a detailed overview of the patient's mental and physical quality of life. Moreover, the QoL-NSP is sensitive to changes due to therapy or other interventions, making it an ideal measure for evaluating the impact of the CoMBI-SMI intervention. It will be administered before TAU, before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a thorough assessment of changes in quality of life.

Of course! The MHQoL-7D was developed in the Netherlands and is a self-report questionnaire. Certainly! The NPI-Q was developed and validated in 2000 and translated into Dutch in 2002. It contains 12 domains that can be used to map neuropsychiatric symptoms. These domains include delusions, hallucinations, agitation/aggression, depression/dysphoria, fear, euphoria/elation, apathy/indifference, disinhibited behavior, irritability/lability, aimless repetitive behavior, night restlessness/sleep disorder, and appetite/eating behavior change. The questionnaire assesses the presence and severity of each symptom, as well as the emotional burden on the caregiver. It will be assessed before the start of treatment as usual (TAU), before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a comprehensive evaluation of changes in symptoms over time.

For the second outcome measure, I recommend considering the Brief Symptom Inventory (BSI). This comprehensive questionnaire assesses psychological and physical symptoms in patients. It covers various domains such as somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, and more. The BSI provides a detailed overview of the patient's symptoms and their severity. It is also sensitive to therapy influences, making it suitable for evaluating the impact of the CoMBI-SMI intervention. Does this measure align with your study objectives?

Absolutely! The BSI is a multidimensional complaints list that assesses the extent to which the patient has experienced psychological and/or physical symptoms during the past period. It consists of 53 items scored on a scale from 0 to 4. There are 9 subscales, including somatic complaints, cognitive problems, interpersonal sensitivity, depressed mood, fear, hostility, phobic fear, paranoid thoughts, and psychoticism. The BSI will be assessed before TAU, before the CoMBI-SMI training, and after 4 weeks of CoMBI-SMI training. This allows for a thorough assessment of changes in symptoms and overall well-being.

The MHQoL-7D covers seven dimensions, including self-esteem, independence, mood, relationships, daily activities, physical health, and future. The total score can range from 0 to 21, with higher scores indicating better quality of life. The MHQoL visual analog scale measures the respondent's general psychological well-being on a scale from zero to ten. Does this measure align with your study objectives?

Here are the comprehensive descriptions of the secondary outcome measures: I.Measure 1: Mean change in Early Treatment Diabetic Retinopathy Study (ETDRS) BCVA from baseline This measure assesses the change in visual acuity using the ETDRS chart. Data will be collected during Week 1, Week 12, Week 24/Final Visit, and 52. When reporting the change in visual acuity, all baseline values will be converted to an appropriate baseline value (i.e., 0.45 logMAR) and set as a fixed value (standardized baseline) to facilitate interpretation.II.Measure 2: Change in CNV size according to fluorescein angiogram This measure evaluates the change in choroidal neovascularization (CNV) size using fundus fluorescein angiography (FFA). Data will be collected during Week 4 and Week 12.The FFA data will be rated by the masked grader, and the change in CNV size will be categorized for each patient (e.g., reduction 20%; no change; increase 50%) then analyzed as a single attribute with the number of patients with a reduction in CNV size as the measured variable.III.Measure 3: Changes in intra- or sub-retinal fluid measured as mean change in central retinal thickness or macula volume This measure assesses the changes in intra- or sub-retinal fluid using spectral domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT). Data will be collected during Week 4 and Week 12.The Central Retinal Thickness (CRT) will be measured in all eyes except for those with severe macular edema that prevented adequate acquisition of the central foveal scan. Eyes with severe macular edema will have macular volume calculated based on a perimetry scan approximately 6 × 6 mm or larger that encompasses the entire macular region.All other patients without severe macular edema will have CRT determined as average retinal thickness centered at the grid line, which will be obtained by the automated macular thickness map centered at the grid line. Data obtained from both grids will be provided from the macular cube scan.The mean change in CRT or macula volume from baseline to Week 4 and Week 12 will be assessed.

model_response: Response inhibition is an important indicator of cognitive control and executive function. The Stop Signal Reaction Time task is one of the most common tasks used in cognitive science to measure response inhibition. It involves instructing the participant to initiate a response to a Go stimulus (e.g., pressing a button) but to inhibit their response when a Stop stimulus (e.g., an auditory tone) is presented along with the Go stimulus. The difference between the reaction time for the task without the Stop signal and during Stop signal trials indicates the strength of the inhibition of the ongoing response. The Stop signal reaction time is a good choice. However, it would be important to select the optimal method for analyzing and interpreting the Stop Signal Reaction Time data. One approach is to use the average Stop Signal Response time across all Stop trials of each participant. This is an alternative choice to the more common method of the “horse race model”, which considers the time difference between the Stop Signal Delay and the Go trial reaction time in each Stop Signal Trial. Also, to capture the effect of the intervention, the Go Stimulus and Stop signal Delay should be appropriate. To determine the appropriate Stop Signal Delay, it might be helpful to run first a pilot study using 50–100 participants 3-5 weeks prior to the start of the trial and to use at least 5 different Stop Signal Delay values as part of the Pilot Study, to select the best value for the final trial.

That's great. We can also use the Stroop Color Word task as a secondary outcome measure. This task can provide additional evidence about participants' ability to inhibit automatic responses and is relatively easy to complete, making it a good option for cognitive testing. The Stroop Color Word task can be used to measure the time taken to name the color the word is printed in, despite the conflict between the print color and the meaning of the word.

The N-Back Test Outcome can be a useful secondary measure as well. It allows us to evaluate participants' capacity to store and process information. In addition, we could potentially include the Stroop Test as another secondary outcome measure.

Yes, that's another useful measure. Incorporating the Stop Signal Delay in our study will give us a deeper insight into the delayed reactions caused by response inhibition. Additionally, it will also help us measure the efficiency of participants' response inhibition. The Stop Signal Delay can be measured as the time participants need to initiate their response after receiving the stop signal.

Definitely! The Individual Coefficient of Variance is an important measure of cognitive ability. This will help us understand participants' variability in reaction times to different stimuli. We can measure the change from baseline to 2-hours post L-Phe supplementation. This will provide insights into how PKU carrier status affects attention and focus.

Yes, measuring changes in N-terminal pro-brain natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP) is very informative. NT-proBNP is a neurohormone produced in response to ventricular stretch that is secreted into the circulation. Its concentration reflects cardiac wall stretch and is considered a marker of cardiac volume overload that is commonly used in the management of heart failure. It plays a primary role in the assessment of left ventricular diastolic dysfunction and heart failure. Changes in NT-proBNP levels indicate the effectiveness of interventions in ameliorating cardiac wall stretch, but it is not a good standalone criterion for diagnosis.

You can describe it as "a change of 30% in NT-proBNP or decrease to a level <1000 compared to baseline." In addition to statistical measures (i.e., mean or median change, standard deviation, or confidence intervals), absolute changes at specified time points can illustrate the magnitude of change from baseline.

An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "up to 12 months." Monitoring changes in NT-proBNP at 12 months after treatment can provide valuable insights into the efficacy and long-term effects of the intervention. This can help in refining and personalizing treatment strategies to achieve optimal results for patients.

The KCRQL measures the quality of life of patients with cardiovascular disease as related to the impact of cardiac magnetic resonance findings. Changes in this score provide a unique perspective on how patients are responding to the condition and their perceived improvement. A 30% change in patient-reported quality of life score compared to baseline would be a measure of interest.
You can describe it as "5-point change in KCQL score compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "12 months." Next, we can monitor changes in N-terminal Propeptide B-type natriuretic peptide (NT-proBNP).

The 6-minute walk test (6-MWT) is a practical test that measures the distance an individual can walk over a period of 6 minutes. It is a valuable indicator of functional capacity and exercise tolerance in heart failure patients and can be used to monitor the effect of treatment on a patient's ability to walk. A 30-meter or more improvement in the 6-minute walk test distance compared to baseline indicates a clinically significant improvement, which can provide valuable insights into the patient's ability to perform physical activities.
You can describe it as "25-meter change in the 6-minute walk test compared to baseline."
An appropriate time frame for this measure would be "6 months."

Thank you for providing all the necessary information. Now, let me summarize the outcome measures we have designed for your clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Physical Activity Scale for the Physically Disabled (PASIPD): This 13-item scale assesses activities of daily living, domestic activities, and professional duties over the last 7 days. The time frame for measuring the PASIPD is 7 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale: This scale consists of 43 items and assesses the individual's level of belief in the benefit of exercise. The time frame for measuring the Exercise Benefits/Barriers Scale is 7 months.
- Berg Balance Scale (BBS): This 14-item scale evaluates balance and fall risk. It measures the patient's ability to maintain balance while performing static or various functional movements. The time frame for measuring the BBS is 7 months.
- International Fall Effectiveness Scale (FES-I): This scale assesses the self-confidence of individuals in daily activities and their fear of falling. The time frame for measuring the FES-I is 7 months.
- Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS): This scale assesses the fatigue status of individuals over the past week. Those with an FSS score of 4 or higher are considered tired. The time frame for measuring the FSS is 7 months.
- Beck Depression Inventory (BDI): This inventory measures the symptoms of depression. It consists of 21 items graded between 0 and 3 points. The time frame for measuring the BDI is 7 months.
- Pittsburgh Sleep Quality Index (PSQI): This scale assesses the quality of sleep and disturbances experienced by individuals over the past month. The time frame for measuring the PSQI is 7 months.

model_response: When evaluating bioequivalence, it is important to consider measures that provide an overall evaluation of the pharmacokinetics, such as the AUC and Cmax. Both measures provide a measure of drug exposure. The AUC allows us to estimate average plasma concentration over time, whereas the Cmax provides a measure of the peak plasma concentration.

There are several ways to measure the AUC and Cmax, but the most commonly used is pharmacokinetic (PK) modeling. This approach involves analyzing blood samples collected from participants at various time points after drug administration. By fitting the data to a model, we can calculate the AUC and Cmax values for each participant and then compare them between the two groups.

The description for the measures of AUC and Cmax should be provided based on the time interval between dosing and sampling. Specifically, AUC can be measured in the blood samples taken at specific times between 0 and 12 hours for the first dose, and 12 and 72 hours for the second dose, and would be expressed as AUC0-12h and AUC12-72h for the first dose, and AUC12-72h and AUC72-72h for the second dose. Similarly, Cmax can be measured in the samples taken at specific times between 0 and 2 hours for the first dose, and 2 and 32 hours for the second dose for each subject, and would be expressed as Cmax0-2h for the first dose, and Cmax2-32h and Cmax32-32h for the second dose.

The length of the study period depends on the particular characteristics of the pharmacokinetics of the drug in the study population. Based on the elimination half-life of Lamotrigine in healthy adult participants, 24 hours post-dose should be sufficient to capture the majority of the AUC. However, it may be beneficial to extend the follow- up period, such as adding additional visits between 24 and 72 hours, to ensure that all the individuals who received the study interventions are free from medication effects, and to capture any possible delayed drug absorption. The total of the study period will last around 36-48 hours after taking study medication. In practice, it will be reasonable to collect the samples every hour until 24 hours, followed by samples at 3, 6, 12, 24, and 48 hours post-dose. For the AUC, this sampling scheme will cover the entire absorption and elimination phases. Additionally, collecting samples at multiple points 48-72 hours post dose can help demonstrate bioequivalence at time points that are beyond the elimination half-life of the drugs. These additional samples also provide an opportunity to monitor the accuracy of the extended follow-up period. With the 48-hour sample as a reference point, blood samples can be taken with longer intervals and, if needed, additional samples can be taken if the 48-hour sample is not well-aligned with the elimination of the drug. Overall, collecting post-dose samples at 3, 6, 12, 24, 36, 48, 72 hours will provide adequate coverage throughout the absorption phase, as well as throughout the initial and late elimination phase.

Certainly! Here are the two primary outcome measures:1.The ratio of the area under the lamotrigine concentration versus time curve from time zero to time 72 hours (AUC0-72h) after single dose administration of both lamotrigine tablets (test and reference) will under fasting conditions.2.The ratio of the maximal lamotrigine concentration after single dose administration (Cmax) of both lamotrigine tablets (test and reference) under fasting conditions.
groundtruth: Certainly! The AUC represents the total exposure of the drug in the body over time, while the Cmax indicates the peak concentration of the drug in the blood after administration. By analyzing both AUC and Cmax, we can assess the rate and extent of drug absorption, which is crucial in determining the bioequivalence of the two Lamotrigine tablets.

To measure the AUC and Cmax, we will collect blood samples at various time points up to 72 hours after the administration of the drug. The sampling schedule will include pre-dose (0) and additional time points such as 0.25, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post-dose.

For the AUC measure, we want to establish bioequivalence by ensuring that the calculated 90% confidence interval (CI) for the ratio of geometric means for AUC72 falls within the range of 80.00%-125.00%. Similarly, for the Cmax measure, the 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means should also fall within 80.00%-125.00%.

We will collect blood samples up to 72 hours post-dose to capture the drug's concentration over an extended period. This timeframe will provide us with insights into the drug's absorption, distribution, and elimination processes.

2. Maximal plasma concentration (Cmax): To establish bioequivalence, the calculated 90% CI for the ratio of geometric means for Cmax should fall within 80.00%-125.00%. Blood sampling will be done at pre-dose (0) and at 0.25, 0.5, 1, 1.5, 2, 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4, 5, 6, 8, 12, 16, 24, 36, 48, and 72 hours post-dose.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Safety index-incidence of adverse reactions/events: Monitor the incidence of adverse reactions/events within 30 minutes after each dose.
2. Safety index-incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events: Assess the incidence of solicited adverse reactions/events within 7 days after each dose.
3. Safety index-incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events: Evaluate the incidence of unsolicited adverse reactions/events within 28/30 days after each dose.
4. Safety index-incidence of serious adverse events: Track the occurrence of serious adverse reactions/events from the beginning of vaccination up to 6 months after the final dose.

Atrial fibrillation can affect heart function and may lead to adverse health outcomes, such as heart failure, cerebral events, and even mortality. Monitoring recurrent episodes of atrial fibrillation offers insight into the overall effect of the condition in these patients. Therefore, we can consider measuring the time spent in arrhythmia as a percentage of one year to give an absolute value when measuring the overall impact of atrial fibrillation. The burden could also be expressed as the total number of hours spent with arrhythmias during the year as a relative value, with the goal to determine the distribution of time spent in arrhythmia and the effect of atrial fibrillation on patients' daily lives. To measure the rate of stroke events in this patient population, we can examine the number of strokes, stroke severity, and stroke-related side effects. This can help us assess the impact of atrial fibrillation on cardiovascular outcomes and provide information for future treatment strategies. We can also measure the number of changes in treatments due to AF detection.

The rate of stroke events can be assessed by documenting any new occurrence of stroke or transient ischemic attack that is not directly related to other causes of stroke or transient ischemic attack, such as haemorrhage. The number of participants with changes in treatment will be assessed by documenting any change in the treatment plan due to the discovery of atrial fibrillation. This includes changes in medication, procedures, or the need for hospitalization due to the discovery of atrial fibrillation. Both measures will be assessed using qualitative data. We will consider them as secondary outcome measures, as they are indirect measures of the effectiveness of atrial fibrillation management. This is the first clinical trial that will evaluate the effect of an atrial fibrillation monitoring strategy after an ICU discharge. Including these outcome measures will give us additional information about the impact of post-discharge AF monitoring.

model_response: Dose-limiting toxicities (DLTs) are serious and sometimes life-threatening adverse events that occur after administering the drug. It's important to monitor the number of participants experiencing DLTs at each dose level in the Dose Escalation part of the study, as this gives us an idea of the safety and tolerability of the drug at different dosage levels. A DLT usually occurs within the first few cycles of initial drug exposure and usually resolves by the time of the next scheduled treatment. If the toxicity is deemed to be unacceptable, it results in dose reduction, treatment cessation, or exclusion from the study. By monitoring the number of participants experiencing DLTs at each dose level, we can better understand how the drug affects participants and help determine the recommended dose for future studies.

The recommended phase 2 dose (RP2D) is determined based on safety and pharmacokinetics data from the Dose Escalation part of the study. The RP2D is the highest dose that has an acceptable safety profile and can be used in future trials. Various factors, such as the number and severity of TEAEs and DLTs, as well as pharmacokinetic parameters such as Cmax, are considered in determining the RP2D.

Monitoring the maximum concentration (Cmax) and area under the curve (AUC) of BAY2862789 after single-dose and multiple-dose allows assessment of the pharmacokinetic profile of the drug. This can provide information on how rapidly BAY2862789 is absorbed in the bloodstream, how extensively it is distributed to various tissues, how rapidly it is removed from the body, and what amount of the drug is delivered to each tissue. This data is used to ensure that the drug is working properly and to identify any potential safety or toxicity issues.

Certainly! The secondary efficacy outcome measure in this clinical trial is the percentage change from baseline in tumor size, calculated using modified Response Evaluation Criteria for Solid Tumors (mRECIST) at 24 weeks post-dosing. This measure is a way to track the effectiveness of the BAY2862789 drug on specific solid tumors. By comparing the size of a tumor at baseline to how much larger or smaller it is at 24 weeks, we can get an idea of how well the drug is working. Tumor responses are measured in terms of percent change in the sum of diameters of target lesions, based on two-dimensional measurements of the maximum tumor size by medical imaging. This measure can help us understand how long participants continue to receive benefit after treatment, and whether this drug can improve outcomes for a particular population of patients with solid tumors.

Yes, the objective response rate (ORR) is a measure used to assess treatment efficacy in cancer patients. The ORR measures the percentage of patients who achieve a partial or complete response to treatment, as determined by blinded independent review committee. A partial response is defined as a decrease in the size of the targeted tumor of at least 30%, and a complete response is defined as a complete disappearance of all targeted tumor lesions. The ORR does not take into account patients who are diagnosed with cancer but do not have any detectable tumors to be measured, or have stable disease.

The disease control rate (DCR) is the percentage of participants who have either a complete or a partial response or stable disease in their best overall response. It is determined by using the best overall response for each participant. The best overall response is the best achieved response from the start of the study treatment to the first instance of disease progression, start of new anti-cancer therapy, or the last tumor assessment.

The duration of response (DOR) is defined as the time elapsed from the date of initial tumor response assessment to the date of disease progression, death, or the most recent visit at which no PD occurred. During the period of follow-up, the disease must have progressed. The DOR of each participant who had SD or PD will be censored on their last visit prior to PD.

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months is defined as the cumulative time from the date of enrollment into the study until documented progression based on RECIST 1.1 or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first. It remains censored at the time of the last follow-up for participants who had no documented disease progression or death. PFS at 6 months provides an early efficacy assessment of the treatment by assessing the rate at which tumors progress or participants die after 6 months of receiving the drug.

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months represents the time from the start of study treatment to the date of death due to any cause or last follow-up (if the participant is still alive). It is an important efficacy measure that indicates how long participants live after receiving treatment.

The measures related to the activation of effector T memory cells and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of interleukin-2 (IL2) and interferon-gamma provide information about the immunological effects of BAY2862789 by assessing the changes in the functionality of immune cells before and after treatment with BAY2862789. These measures may help us understand how BAY2862789 affects the immune system of people with solid tumors and how it can modulate anticancer immunity.

The objective response rate (ORR) is defined as the proportion of participants whose best overall response is either a confirmed complete response (CR) or confirmed partial response (PR) according to Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors version 1.1 (RECIST 1.1). ORR helps us assess how effective BAY2862789 is in shrinking or stabilizing tumors.

The disease control rate (DCR) is defined as the percentage of participants whose best overall response was either complete response (CR), partial response (PR), or stable disease (SD). DCR considers the requirement for confirmation of CR and PR. It provides a broader understanding of the treatment's impact on disease control by considering not only tumor shrinkage but also stability.

The duration of response (DOR) is defined as the time from the first documented objective response of PR or CR, whichever occurs earlier, to disease progression or death (if death occurs before progression is documented). It helps us understand how long the treatment's effects last in terms of tumor response. DOR is an important measure of the sustainability of treatment response.

Progression-free survival (PFS) at 6 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to the date of first observed disease progression by investigator assessment or death due to any cause, if death occurs before progression is documented. It provides valuable information on the treatment's ability to delay disease progression for at least 6 months.

Overall survival (OS) at 12 months measures the time from the start of study treatment to death due to any cause. It helps us evaluate the treatment's impact on prolonging overall survival. OS at 12 months provides important information on the long-term benefits of BAY2862789.

Monitoring the activation of effector T memory cells and ex vivo stimulated short-term activation of IL2 and interferon-gamma helps us assess the immunological effects of BAY2862789. groundtruth:
Great! We have now discussed the primary and secondary outcome measures for your clinical trial. Here they are:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. Albumin degradation rate by stable isotope:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to determine the catabolic rate of albumin by measuring the disappearance rate of 2H5-phenylalanine labeled albumin over time in blood samples. It will be compared between patients with liver disease and healthy volunteers.
   - Time Frame: The albumin degradation rate will be measured over a period of 12 weeks.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Albumin synthesis rate:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure involves comparing the oral flooding dose with historical controls where the isotope was given intravenously to measure albumin synthesis rates in volunteers and patients with liver disease.
   - Time Frame: The albumin synthesis rate will be assessed within 120 minutes after the administration of the stable isotope labeled amino acid.

2. Albumin degradation by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over time:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure aims to investigate the relationship between oxidation and degradation of albumin by modeling different fractions of oxidized albumin over a period of 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The modeling of albumin degradation based on oxidized fractions will be conducted over a 12-week period.

3. Correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin:
   - Measure Description: This outcome measure seeks to determine if there is a correlation between oxidation fraction and albumin degradation rate, particularly in patients with liver disease over 12 weeks.
   - Time Frame: The correlation between oxidation and degradation rate of albumin will be assessed over a 12-week period.

I suggest using either the parallel groups or the cluster randomization design. For parallel groups design, each participant would be randomized to either the hybrid mesh group or the non-hybrid mesh group. For cluster randomization, multiple hospitals would be randomized to either the hybrid mesh group or the non-hybrid mesh group. By conducting a cluster randomization design, you can minimize contamination between groups as surgeons may be more likely to use the mesh type assigned to them than switching to another type of mesh. Additionally, conducting a cluster randomized study allows each hospital or surgical team to act as its internal control, which can improve the statistical power and precision of the study compared to individual randomization. Absolutely. Let's go through the secondary outcome measures one by one. The first measure is the Brief Pain Inventory - Numeric Rating Scale. This measure assesses pain intensity by asking about worst and least pain intensity in the past 24 hours, pain on average, and pain right now. It uses an 11-point scale, with zero representing 'no pain' and 10 representing the 'worst imaginable pain'. This measure has been shown to have excellent reliability and validity in people with knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is the Modified Charlson Comorbidity Index (CCI). This measure assesses the presence of comorbidities in participants, including knee osteoarthritis. The CCI has been widely used in various patient populations, including knee osteoarthritis. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks and 3 months.

The next measure is endogenous pain modulation, which assesses the efficiency of pain modulation mechanisms in individuals with knee osteoarthritis. We can use the conditioned pain modulation (CPM) testing method to evaluate this measure. By assessing the ascending measure of pressure pain threshold (PPT) at the anterior shin and the conditioning stimulus in the form of forearm ischemia, we can calculate the percent efficiency of CPM (%CPM) as PPT2/PPT1 multiplied by 100. This measure can provide insights into the neurobiological effects of the intervention. We can assess this measure at 9 weeks.

The other secondary outcome measures include pain interference, pain catastrophizing, Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale (HADS), Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS), multi-joint pain assessed through a body diagram, knee awareness, functional leg strength, medication use, adverse events, patient global impression of change, blinding effectiveness, usefulness of the program for managing knee OA, frequency of the program, duration of the program, acceptability of the delivery of the brain stimulation, acceptability of the delivery of the yoga session of the program, likelihood of recommending the program to others with knee OA, burdensomeness of completing questionnaires and physical assessments, adherence rate, and rate of completion of home sessions. Each of these measures serves a specific purpose and provides valuable information on various aspects of the intervention and study outcomes.

Certainly! The "Timed up & go Test" measures the total time taken for a participant to arise from a chair, walk 3 meters, turn around, return to the chair, and sit down. It is recorded to the nearest 10th of a second. This test will be conducted on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery to assess immediate postoperative functional ability.

The "Numeric Pain Rating Scale" is an 11-point scale that quantifies pain intensity, ranging from 0 (no pain) to 10 (the most intense pain imaginable). Participants will be asked to rate their pain levels up to four days after surgery, allowing us to evaluate the effectiveness of the nerve block in managing postoperative pain.

The "Quadriceps Muscle Strength" will be measured using a dynamometer in N⋅m units. This outcome measure assesses the participants' muscle strength and will be evaluated a day before surgery, the first day after surgery, and the third or fourth day after surgery to monitor changes and improvements in muscle function.

I'm glad you find them appropriate. Now, let's discuss the secondary outcome measures. These measures provide additional insights into various aspects of the participants' recovery and overall outcomes.

For the secondary outcome measures, I suggest considering the "Elderly Mobility Scale", the "5 Times Sit to Stand Test", the "Hospitalization Duration", the "Surgery Duration", the "Consumption of Analgesics", the "Occurrence of Falls", and the "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire". These measures will help assess mobility, lower limb strength, hospitalization duration, surgical complexity, pain management, falls, and knee function, respectively.

Certainly! The "Elderly Mobility Scale" is a validated assessment tool that measures the mobility and independence of elderly participants. It uses an ordinal scale of 0-20, with scores indicating different levels of mobility and independence. This measure will be assessed on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery.

The "5 Times Sit to Stand Test" measures the time taken for a patient to transfer from a seated to a standing position and back to sitting five times. This test evaluates lower limb strength and functional mobility and will be assessed on the first day after surgery and the third or fourth day after surgery.

"Hospitalization Duration" measures the number of days the participants spend hospitalized after surgery. It provides insights into the recovery progress and potential complications. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

"Surgery Duration" measures the duration of the surgical procedure and provides insights into the procedural aspects and their potential influence on recovery and outcomes. This measure will be recorded during the surgery.

"Consumption of Analgesics" measures the amount of analgesics consumed by the participants post-surgery. It helps in assessing the effectiveness of pain management strategies, including the nerve block. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

"Occurrence of Falls" assesses the occurrence of falls during hospitalization, which can have significant implications for patient safety and recovery. This measure will be assessed at discharge, up to day 10.

The "Oxford Knee Score Questionnaire" is a patient-reported outcome measure that assesses knee function and severity of problems related to knee arthritis. It provides a single summed score reflecting the severity of knee problems. This measure will be assessed a day before surgery.

model_response: The time frame for assessing the change in CAP score is 3 months. Participants will be regularly assessed throughout the study period, and the primary outcome measure will be assessed during the baseline visit and at the end of month 3. Changes in liver enzymes (Ala and Asp) were chosen as one of the secondary outcomes measures for several reasons. Firstly, elevated liver enzymes (ALT and AST) levels are commonly found in patients with NAFLD. These enzymes are released from liver cells into the bloodstream when liver tissue is damaged due to inflammation or injury in NAFLD patients. Therefore, monitoring changes in liver enzyme levels can indicate changes in liver function and tissue health. Secondly, changes in liver enzymes can provide insights into metabolic conditions such as obesity and hyperlipidemia. Elevated Ala levels are associated with obesity and insulin resistance, while Asp levels are more strongly linked to hyperlipidemia. Thirdly, observing changes in liver enzymes can help assess the efficacy of treatments being evaluated for NAFLD. By monitoring Ala and Asp levels, researchers can determine the effectiveness of treatments in reducing liver enzyme elevation, which can help prevent further liver damage and liver failure.

Changes in fasting lipid levels, including total cholesterol, triglyceride, and high-density lipoprotein cholesterol (HDL-C), were included as secondary outcome measures to assess improvements in metabolic health. Subjects with NAFLD often have increased lipid levels and elevated total cholesterol, triglycerides, and LDL-C, while decreased HDL-C is typical in these patients. SIM01 intervention may show improvements in these metrics through its ability to influence cholesterol and glucose metabolism or enhance insulin sensitivity, all of which are important risk factors for coronary artery disease (CAD).

Changes in fasting lipid profiles and HbA1c levels will be assessed at baseline and 3 months after taking SIM01. The study is designed to observe the short-term changes in these parameters to provide insights into the potential benefits of SIM01 in improving metabolic function during a 3-month intervention period.

Changes in fasting lipid and HbA1c levels were chosen as secondary outcome measures because they are important markers of metabolic health and are commonly dysregulated in individuals with NAFLD. By assessing the changes in lipid profiles and HbA1c levels, researchers can evaluate the potential benefits of SIM01 in improving metabolic parameters in NAFLD patients.

Certainly! Here are the full outcome measures for this study:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Change in Controlled Attenuation Parameter (CAP) score by fibroscan after taking SIM01 for 3 months: The change of CAP score measured by fibroscan. The CAP score is a measurement of fat accumulation in the liver to further determine the steatosis grade. The higher the score, the more severe the steatosis is. This measure assesses the impact of SIM01 on liver fat accumulation.

These outcome measures will help researchers evaluate the effectiveness of SIM01 in improving liver function, metabolic health, body weight management, abdominal obesity, and immune response in female subjects with NAFLD.

model_response: Another outcome measure I suggest including is the Water Swallow Test (WST), a component of the MD Anderson Dysphagia Inventory (MDADI). The MDA-D is a patient-reported outcome that includes information on functional dysphagia, severity of swallow-related changes, social disability due to dysphagia, and emotional distress due to swallowing. The Water Swallow Test evaluates the thickness of liquid needed to trigger the swallow response and how hard the patient swallows. These measurements are collected using a flexible, fiberscope passed to the back of patient's nasopharynx.

Great question. The time frame for evaluating the FOIS is typically on a daily basis during the treatment period. An additional measure to consider is the Dysphagia Severity Scale (DSS), which evaluates oral dysphagia based on 6 clinical characteristics: safety, ability to handle secretions, bolus integrity, efficacy/efficiency of swallowing, quality of swallowing, and dysphagia symptoms. Each characteristic is rated on a scale of 0 to 12 points, with a higher score indicating more severe oral dysphagia.

For the PAS, we recommend conducting videofluoroscopic evaluation at baseline and at the end of the 3-week treatment period. This will allow you to evaluate the level of aspiration risk during swallowing at baseline and compare it with the risk after the treatment period.

The final primary outcome measure I suggest is the Patient Assessment Swallowing Questionnaire (PASQ-16). It's a 16-item questionnaire that assesses swallowing-related problems and how they impact a patient's quality of life from their perspective. The PASQ-16 will be evaluated on a scale of 0 to 4 for each item, with higher scores indicating a greater impact on the patient's quality of life. This measure will provide valuable information about the patient's perceived impact of the intervention.

The DHI is scored using a 5-point Likert-type scale. Scores range from "not at all" to "depends a lot/almost always" for each statement. A cut-off score of 10 points or more out of 100 indicates a degree of dysphagia that requires intervention treatment. Lower scores on the DHI indicate a better quality of life and less disability. The DHI is evaluated at baseline and at the end of the treatment.

There isn't a specific time frame for evaluating the DHI. It can be administered at any point during the treatment period. Certainly! Here are the measure description and time frame for each of the secondary outcome measures:

1. Decision-to-departure time: Time from decision for MT to departure of the patient from the primary stroke center to the primary thrombectomy center. Time frame: 24 hours.

2. Decision-to-arrival time: Time from decision for MT to arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center. Time frame: 24 hours.

3. Arrival-to-groin time: Time from arrival of the patient at the primary thrombectomy center to groin puncture (start of mechanical thrombectomy procedure). Time frame: 24 hours.

4. Rate of refusal of transfer requests due to lack of capacity: Rate of patients that had to be transferred to a secondary thrombectomy center instead of the primary thrombectomy center due to lack of capacity in the referral clinic. Time frame: 24 hours.

5. Decision-to-transfer request time: Time from decision for MT to request of emergency medical service for interhospital transfer. Time frame: 24 hours.

6. Periprocedural complications: Rate of periprocedural complications during MT. Time frame: 24 hours.

7. Successful outcome of MT (mTICI > 2b): Rate of successfully performed MT (mTICI > 2b) of all patients with attempted MT. Time frame: 24 hours.

8. Groin-to-recanalization time: Time from groin puncture to successful recanalization. Time frame: 24 hours.

9. Adverse events within 7 days: Adverse events within the first 7 days after transfer to the referral center. Time frame: 7 days.

groundtruth:
Absolutely! In addition to the CR/CRh rate, there are several other important secondary outcome measures to consider. These include:

1. Incidence and severity of adverse events (safety and tolerability): We can monitor the number and grade of adverse events assessed by CTCAE v5.0 over the course of approximately 36 months. This will help us assess the safety and tolerability of the combination therapy.

2. Duration of response: Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression or death in patients who achieve CR/CRh will provide insights into the durability of treatment response.

3. Post baseline transfusion independence rate: Assessing the rate of conversion from baseline transfusion dependence to transfusion independence will help us understand the impact of treatment on patients' quality of life.

4. Progression-free survival: Evaluating the time from randomization until the first evidence of disease progression or death will provide valuable information on the treatment's ability to control disease progression and prolong survival.

5. Relapse-free survival: Monitoring the number of participants alive without relapse will help us assess the long-term effectiveness of the combination therapy in preventing disease relapse.

6. Overall survival: Measuring the time from randomization to death will provide essential data on the treatment's impact on overall survival outcomes.

7. Percentage of patients bridged to hematopoietic stem cell transplantation: Assessing the number of hematopoietic stem cell transplantations following response will provide insights into the potential of the combination therapy to facilitate curative treatment options.

8. Impact of treatment on HM-PRO (hematologic malignancy-specific patient-reported outcome measure): Evaluating the treatment's impact on patients' health-related quality of life and disease-related signs and symptoms using the HM-PRO scales will provide a holistic understanding of the treatment's effects.

One particular measure that may be useful for assessing socioemotional development is the MacArthur-Bates Communicative Development Inventories (CDI). The CDI is a language-independent scale that can assess children's early cognitive and socioemotional development. It consists of 5 CDI words checklists and contains 353 words that cover 422 skills developmental items organized in semantic categories. Another measure that can be used to assess socioemotional development is the Strengths and Difficulties Questionnaire (SDQ). I would suggest considering the following outcome measures:
1. Auditory brainstem response (ABR) intensity: This measure provides objective information about the integrity of the auditory pathway from the ear to the brainstem. It can help monitor the progression of hearing loss in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure ABR intensity at different time points throughout the study, such as annually for 4 years.

Another important measure is otoacoustic emission (OAEs) amplitudes. OAEs are a non-invasive measure of cochlear function and can provide information about the health of the outer hair cells in the cochlea. Monitoring OAEs amplitudes can help assess the structural integrity of the cochlea and detect early signs of cochlear dysfunction in pediatric participants with gene-related hearing loss. We can also measure OAEs amplitudes annually for 4 years.

Yes, we should include pure tone intensity thresholds as an outcome measure. This measure assesses the softest sound that a participant can hear at different frequencies. It's crucial for evaluating the degree and configuration of hearing loss and tracking changes in hearing sensitivity over time in pediatric participants with OTOF, GJB2, or GJB2/GJB6 mutations. We can measure pure tone intensity thresholds annually for 4 years as well.

The last outcome measure I would recommend is speech detection and perception thresholds. This measure evaluates the ability of participants to detect and perceive speech sounds at different intensity levels. It's important for understanding the impact of gene-related hearing loss on speech understanding and communication abilities in pediatric participants. We can assess speech detection and perception thresholds annually for 4 years.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest focusing on auditory skills and speech perception over time. We can include measures such as open- and closed-set task phoneme accuracy and word comprehension, early speech perception (ESP), pediatric speech intelligibility (PSI) test, and auditory skills checklist (ASC). We can assess these measures annually for 4 years as well.

The muscle index (MI), also known as the pressure muscle index (PMI), is a measurement of the pressure above positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) generated by closing the airways briefly and then opening them abruptly, giving a value in centimeters of water (cmH2O). In practice, the measurement is often obtained during the pressure cycling phase, also known as expiration, when the airways are already open. The muscle index has been observed to be highly related to the mechanical power output that can be generated by the major muscle groups involved in coughing.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Pressure muscle index (PMI) as a bedside estimation of inspiratory effort at different expiratory cycling levels during different levels of pressure support ventilation. Measure Description: To verify whether PMI correlates differently with esophageal pressure swing by changing expiratory cycling over different levels of pressure support ventilation. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Correlation between PMI and other measures of inspiratory effort (Pocc) and inspiratory drive (P0.1). Measure Description: To evaluate the correlation between different measures of inspiratory effort and inspiratory drive with PMI obtained at various degrees of expiratory cycling and different levels of pressure support. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Airway resistances during assisted mechanical ventilation. Measure Description: To evaluate if airway resistance, evaluated by esophageal pressure, correlates with the estimation of airway resistance on the pressure-time waveform. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.
- Tidal volume variability. Measure Description: To evaluate tidal variability across different levels of pressure support ventilation and different levels of expiratory cycling and investigate how tidal variability correlates with inspiratory effort using deltaPes, PMI, and Pocc. Time Frame: After at least 6 hours and within 72 hours since the switch to pressure support ventilation.

Great, your choice of the frequency diet volume ratio as the primary outcome measure is appropriate based on the intervention. We often use measures with counts or proportion form as a primary outcome measure for a research question which seeks frequency of occurrence. By definition, your frequency of diet volume ratio is a count or an integer representing the number of times diet volume ratio reaches a criterion on a daily basis. You don’t want to collect the data using a nominal scale such as Yes/No since it will not provide a numerical value to describe practical implications of the intervention. In addition, we should assess how often diet volume ratio reaches a defined criterion rather than evaluate the diet volume ratio itself. Therefore, we want to measure the number of times when diet volume ratio reaches one of the thresholds. I recommend measuring “diet volume ratio count” as a frequency of diet volume ratio as the dichotomous variable. The diet volume ratio count is a count of diet volume ratio at a specific time interval, and therefore it is a continuous numeric data. We can set a criterion that the criterion of interest occurs when ≥ n times each day (e.g., ≥1 time, ≥2 times, etc.), as appropriate for your study, or the ratio ≥ k × 100, e.g., ≥ 50 times). Then, we will perform contingeneity analysis for diet volume ratio count ≥ criterion of interest.

PFS measures the time from the initial date of treatment to documented progression or death in the absence of progression. On the other hand, OS measures the time from the initial date of treatment to the recorded date of death. These measures will provide valuable information about disease progression and overall survival, helping to evaluate the long-term effectiveness and benefits of the treatment. Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Progression-free survival (PFS): Measured from the initial date of treatment to documented progression or death. The time frame for this measure is 5 years.
- Overall survival (OS): Measured from the initial date of treatment to the recorded date of death. The time frame for this measure is also 5 years.

Absolutely! Here are some suggestions for secondary outcome measures related to the surgical procedure:

1. Hydraulic pressure during surgery: This measure assesses the difference in pressure administered by the arthrpomp (a device used during the surgery) between the beginning and the end of the procedure. It provides insights into the efficiency of the surgical process and the impact of anesthesia on it.

2. The intensity of bleeding during surgery: This measure evaluates the intensity of bleeding during the procedure, which can be assessed by the number of washes performed. It helps determine the impact of anesthesia on intraoperative bleeding.

3. Sedation administered to the patient during surgery: This measure assesses the type of sedation administered to the patient, such as no sedation, hypnotic sedation, or morphine sedation. Understanding the impact of different sedation methods on patient outcomes and comfort is crucial.

Certainly! Here are some suggestions for outcome measures related to patient experience and recovery:

1. Patient pain after surgery: This measure assesses the level of pain experienced by the patient using a visual analogue scale over 100 mm. It will be measured in the morning and evening during the first 3 days after surgery, and then once on day 7, day 14, and day 21. Tracking pain levels helps evaluate the effectiveness of pain management strategies under different anesthesia methods.

2. Patient satisfaction 3 weeks after surgery: This measure evaluates patient satisfaction with the surgery using a 4-point Likert scale. Positive and negative points will be collected in comments to gather more detailed feedback on the surgical experience.

3. Adverse events between patients operated on loco-regional anesthesia alone and patients on loco-regional anesthesia and general anesthesia: This measure focuses on monitoring the number and type of adverse events noted during the procedure and in the 6 months post-operation. It helps assess the safety and potential risks associated with different anesthesia methods.

4. Medication taken for pain between these same groups of patients in the 21 days following surgery: This measure tracks the patient's daily consumption of painkillers, recorded in a patient diary for 21 days after the intervention. It provides insights into the pain management needs and recovery progress of patients under different anesthesia methods.

You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your clinical trial on rotator cuff repair under isolated loco-regional anesthesia!

model_response: There are a few areas we can consider for secondary outcome measures. One is kinesthesia. It is an important aspect of body function in activities of daily living and in motor control training. For kinesthesia assessment, we can use a subjective rating scale based on the sensation of movement such as a gradual increase in the intensity of the kinesthetic sensation during muscle contractions. We can also use other methods such as a kinematic assessment of the arm to assess kinesthesia. Another area we can consider is the ability of the participants to execute specific motor tasks. We can assess their ability to move from one point in space to another in relation to a goal in a functional task. This can be done using a robotic device or a non-robotic device. In addition to the primary outcome measures of depression and anxiety, the following secondary outcome measures will also be used in the clinical trial: (1) Self-Care of Neurological Disorders: Self-Efficacy Scale (SCAND-SE; English version) is used to assess self-efficacy, which is defined as one's belief in one's own ability to successfully manage day-to-day activities in life. It consists of a questionnaire with a total of 30 items scored from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating better self-efficacy. (2) Profile of Mood State for Adults (POMS-RA) is a short version of the adult POMS used to measure anxiety and depression. The scale consists of 42 items rated from 0 to 4, with higher scores indicating greater anxiety and depression. (3) Five Facet Mindfulness Questionnaire-Revised (FFMQ-R) is an 18-item self-report questionnaire that measures the level of mindfulness in individuals assessed. The scale ranges from 1 to 7, with higher scores indicating greater mindfulness. (4) Multidimensional Fatigue Inventory (MFI) is a validated measure of subjective fatigue and level of energy that consists of 20 items scored from 1 to 5, with higher scores indicating greater fatigue. (5) Modified Fatigue Impact Scale (MFIS) is a self-report scale used to measure the impact of fatigue on physical, cognitive, and psychosocial functioning. It consists of 39 items scored on an 11-point scale, with higher scores indicating greater fatigue. (6) EuroQol (EQ-5D-5L) is a self-report measure of quality of life that measures five dimensions of health, including mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/uncomfortable symptoms, and anxiety/depression. It is scored from 0 to 100, with higher scores indicating higher quality of life.

The General Self-Efficacy Scale (GSES) assesses self-efficacy, while the University of Washington Self-Efficacy Scale focuses specifically on MS-specific self-efficacy. The University of Washington Resilience Scale measures resilience. The COPE inventory assesses coping strategies. The Benefit Finding in Multiple Sclerosis (BFIMS) measures positive coping. Lastly, the Ryff Psychological Well-being Scales (RYFFPWB) assess psychological well-being.

Excellent suggestions for the secondary outcome measures! Including these measures will provide a comprehensive assessment of the impact of different TXA administration strategies on various aspects of coagulation, bleeding, seizures, thromboembolic events, and postoperative outcomes. Let's summarize the outcome measures we have so far:

Primary Outcome Measure:
1. CRT maximal amplitude: This measure assesses the maximal amplitude of the CRT test, reflecting the overall coagulation profile of the patient within 24 hours.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. CK reaction time: The value of the r-time of the CK test.
2. CK alpha angle: The value of the alpha angle of the CK test.
3. CRT maximal lysis: The value of maximal lysis of the CRT test.
4. CFF maximal amplitude: The value of maximal amplitude of the CFF test.
5. Hemoglobin: Serum hemoglobin value.
6. Packed RBC: Number of units of transfused packed RBC within 6 hours.
7. Fresh frozen plasma: Number of units of transfused fresh frozen plasma within 6 hours.
8. Cryoprecipitate: Number of units of transfused cryoprecipitate within 6 hours.
9. Platelet: Number of units of transfused platelet (apheresis) or platelet concentrate within 6 hours.
10. Seizure: Incidence of postoperative seizure within 48 hours.
11. Thromboembolism: Incidence of postoperative myocardial infarction, cerebral infarction, pulmonary thrombosis, and intestinal infarction within 48 hours.
12. Postoperative bleeding: Amount of bleeding from surgical drains within 48 hours.
13. Re-operation: Incidence of re-operation due to postoperative bleeding within 48 hours.

Here is a list of the primary and secondary outcome measures, along with the specific measures within each category, descriptions, and time frames:Primary Outcome Measures Adverse Events (AE) and Serious Adverse Events (SAE)Any AE that occurs during or soon after the study drug administration. An AE is defined as any unfavorable medical event, unintended injury, or illness occurring in a treatment recipient or potential recipient, whether considered drug-related or not, which does not necessarily need to have a causal relationship with the administration of the study drug. A serious adverse event (SAE) is any medical occurrence that results in death, is life-threatening, or requires hospitalization or an extension thereof, or results in persistent or significant disability. All AEs are recorded at the time of occurrence and followed until resolution, recovery, or disappearance. The investigator will evaluate all collected safety-related information and assess causality of all recorded AEs. The investigator may determine that other adverse events during the study that are additional to the initial AE may be related to the same causal event. Any related AE must be combined into the initial AE and updated with additional information (e.g., additional information on severity, duration, nature, course, or causal relationship). Any AE that occurred during a previous study and continued until beyond the end of the study or that has a causality assessment carried over from a previous study must follow the above rules for the relevant AE. For all SAE, the investigator must submit a written report to the ISR within the time frame outlined in the local regulations. If the investigator believes that the study drug is the cause of an AE, the AE is considered drug-related. All Aes will be grouped as either drug-related or non-drug-related. Time from study drug administration to resolution of the AE should indicate if the study drug caused the particular AE. AE assessments are made based on physical examination, medical history, laboratory studies, and concomitant medication use and are evaluated to determine if the events are caused by the study drug. Other AEs may be of concern and may require careful monitoring but may not necessarily be followed by the ISR. These include, but are not limited to, the following: Pregnancy. Primary Outcome Measure:

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Estimating the inter-individual variations of the free circulating methylome of renal origin in patients with end-stage chronic insufficiency: The amount of renal-cell-free DNA (glomerular and tubular markers) measured will be compared between individuals using the same time frame.
- Identify by a method without a priori (methyl seq) specific markers of acute renal injury in terms of epigenetic signature: Comparison of two biomarker quantification methods (whole genome methyl-Sequencing and multiplex digital-PCR) using the same time frame.
- Study the statistical association between the presence of free circulating methylated sequences of renal origin and the resumption of graft function: Comparison of circulating free methylome of renal origin between the groups of patients with immediate recovery of function and delayed recovery using a time frame of 7 days after the transplant.

2. Quality of life: It will be analyzed on the basis of the adapted OHIP-14Sp questionnaire, which consists of 14 questions grouped into seven categories. Time frame: 6 months.
3. Subjective Masticatory Performance: It will be analyzed on the basis of the adapted QMF questionnaire, which consists of 29 questions related to the frequency and ease of chewing different types of food. Time frame: 6 months.
4. Sialometry and salivary pH: Unstimulated and stimulated salivary secretion will be measured, along with salivary pH. Time frame: 6 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Oral Health Status: It will be evaluated using the DMFT index and the CPI. Time frame: 6 months.
2. Patient Satisfaction: Patients will be asked to rate their satisfaction with the prosthetic rehabilitation on a scale of 1-10. Time frame: 6 months.

1. "Number of sport units per week, sport disciplines practiced": This measure will provide valuable information on the level of physical activity and sports participation of patients post-surgery. Changes in range of motion can indicate improvements or limitations in mobility and flexibility post-surgery.
4. "Subjective change of instability after surgery": Using a visual analog scale to assess subjective changes in instability post-surgery will provide valuable information on patients' perception of their joint stability. This outcome measure allows for the evaluation of functional outcomes related to stability and balance following the surgical intervention.

"Change of pain after surgery": Measuring changes in pain levels using a visual analog scale is important in assessing the effectiveness of the surgical intervention in reducing pain associated with insertional Achilles tendinopathy. Patients' pain levels can significantly impact their ability to participate in sports and physical activities.
6. "Satisfaction with result": Assessing patients' satisfaction with the surgical result using a visual analog scale provides insight into their overall experience and outcomes following the intervention. Patient satisfaction is an important indicator of treatment success and can influence their quality of life and willingness to engage in sports activities.

"Satisfaction with result": The measure for satisfaction with the surgical result will be assessed using a visual analog scale ranging from 0 to 10, where 0 means not satisfied and 10 means maximum satisfaction. This measure should also be assessed a minimum of 12 months from surgery to follow-up.

groundtruth: Certainly! Uncorrected distance visual acuity (UDVA) measures the patient's ability to see without correction, while corrected distance visual acuity (CDVA) measures their vision with correction. Both UDVA and CDVA will be measured using the logarithm of minimal angle of resolution (logMAR) scale. Sphere and cylinder will be measured in diopters (D) to assess refractive errors, and keratometry (Kmax) will also be measured in diopters to evaluate corneal steepness and shape alterations. These measurements will be taken at 36 months to evaluate the long-term effects of each protocol.

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend assessing endothelial cell density and central corneal thickness. Endothelial cell density will be measured in cells/mm^2 to evaluate the impact of the cross-linking protocols on the corneal endothelium. Central corneal thickness will be measured in micrometers (um) to monitor corneal remodeling, swelling, or thinning post-treatment. Both of these measures will also be evaluated at the 36-month mark.

That's correct! You have designed a comprehensive set of outcome measures for your study. These measures will provide valuable insights into the effectiveness and safety of the different cross-linking protocols for treating pediatric keratoconus. Primary Outcome Measure:
- Objective response rate (ORR) determined by investigators according to RECIST 1.1: This measure assesses the percentage of participants who achieve a best overall response (BOR) of confirmed Complete Response (CR) or Partial Response (PR).

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Incidence and severity of adverse events (AEs): This measure evaluates the AEs related to the drug and assesses their incidence and severity.
- Observed maximum plasma concentration (Cmax) of HS-20093: This measure determines the highest observed concentration of the drug in plasma.
- Time to reach maximum plasma concentration (Tmax) of HS-20093 following the first dose: This measure assesses the time it takes for the drug to reach its highest concentration in plasma.
- Terminal half-life (T1/2) of HS-20093 following the first dose: This measure calculates the time for the drug concentration to decrease by half.
- Area under plasma concentration versus time curve from zero to last sampling time (AUC0-t) following the first dose of HS-20093: This measure evaluates the drug's systemic exposure over time.
- Percentage of participants with antibodies to HS-20093 in serum: This measure assesses the presence of antibodies to the drug in participants' serum.
- Objective response rate (ORR) determined by Independent review committee (IRC) according to RECIST 1.1: This measure provides an unbiased evaluation of the drug's efficacy.
- Duration of response (DoR) determined by investigators and IRC according to RECIST 1.1: This measure assesses the sustainability of the drug's efficacy.
- Disease control rate (DCR) determined by investigators and IRC according to RECIST 1.1: This measure evaluates the overall impact of the drug on disease control.
- Progression-free survival (PFS) determined by investigators and IRC according to RECIST 1.1: This measure assesses the drug's impact on disease progression and survival outcomes.
- 4-month PFS rate determined by investigators and IRC according to RECIST 1.1: This measure evaluates disease progression and survival outcomes at 4 months.
- Overall survival (OS): This measure assesses the drug's impact on long-term survival outcomes.

- Primary Outcome Measure: Prostate cancer upstaging - Compare the accuracy of rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT with conventional imaging for detecting metastatic disease and up-staging of disease in men with high-risk prostate cancer. Time frame: 15 months.
- Secondary Outcome Measures:
  1. Verified Detection Rate of rhPSMA-7.3 - Assess the Verified Detection Rate (VDR) for M1 disease of rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT findings on a patient level in men with high-risk prostate cancer. Time frame: 15 months.
  2. Positive predictive value of rhPSMA-7.3 - Assess the VDR and determine PPV for M1 disease of rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT findings on a patient level in patients with negative conventional imaging. Time frame: 15 months.
  3. Metastasis detection rate - Percentage of patients in which rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT imaging detects at least one verified M1 metastasis, as determined by central BIE. Time frame: 15 months.
  4. Metastasis detection rate with negative imaging - Percentage of patients with negative conventional imaging for M1 disease in whom rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT detects at least one verified M1 metastasis, as determined by central BIE. Time frame: 15 months.
  5. Positive predictive value of rhPSMA compared to biopsy - The PPV of rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT to detect distant disease compared to biopsy in those patients who undergo a distant disease biopsy on the basis of a rhPSMA-7.3 PET/CT finding or in case of bony disease a correlation with MRI or biopsy. Time frame: 15 months.

model_response: Certainly! The EDSS is a widely used, reliable, and valid measure of disability over time (1). A score of 6.0 is typically considered to be the threshold for needing use of a wheelchair full-time (2).

model_response: Of course! Let me briefly explain each of the primary outcome measures. VO2max (maximal oxygen consumption) is a measure of an individual's maximum rate of oxygen consumption during physical activity. It is a primary measure of aerobic fitness and serves as an indicator of an individual's general physical health status. VO2max is typically assessed indirectly using extrapolation of gas exchange data obtained during a submaximal exercise test. Exercise duration refers to the length of time a person can engage in an activity without becoming fatigued. It is an indicator of endurance and can help to determine the best exercise intensity. The Modified Borg Scale is a rating scale used to measure perceived exertion. It was first developed by Borg in the 1980s and has been modified to evaluate fatigue levels during exercise. It uses a combination of numbers and descriptors at various exercise intensities to provide a quantitative assessment of fatigue. Lastly, lactate levels are a measure of biological stress during exercise. As people exercise, their muscles produce lactate. High lactate levels during exercise are an indication of anaerobic capacity, which is a limitation on exercise performance. Assessing lactate levels during exercise can provide insights into an individual's athletic performance and training methods.

Exercise duration is another primary outcome measure we could consider. We can track how long the participants can tolerate the aerobic exercise after each ozone therapy session. The idea is to compare the exercise duration before the first ozone treatment and after each subsequent ozone therapy session. This will help us assess if the ozone therapy impacts the time participants can sustain exercise.

The Modified Borg Scale is a 10-point scale that is commonly used to measure perceived fatigue during and after exercising. It has been shown to have good validity and reliability in healthy adults. At the start of the exercise test, participants can use the scale to rate the intensity of their fatigue before engaging in exercise (during the warm-up phase). They can then rate their fatigue at 30-second intervals throughout the exercise test, and immediately after the exercise is complete. We can use this scale to assess the effects of ozone therapy on perceived fatigue during and after the exercise test.

Lactate levels are often measured during anaerobic exercise conditions. The level of lactate in blood or other tissues is determined by the balance between the production and removal of lactate. The levels can decrease during moderate or low-intensity exercises, depending on participants' athletic conditioning. However, during high-intensity exercise, lactate levels increase, leading to decreasing exercise performance. Comments: Progression-free survival (PFS) is a well-accepted and widely used outcome measure in oncology trials. Comparisons of PFS are usually made between treatment groups to assess whether the treatment under evaluation is more effective in delaying disease progression and improving patient survival. PFS can be defined as the duration of time from the start of therapy to disease progression, or the first occurrence of an adverse event, or death. Progression or deterioration of symptoms is usually defined based on a combination of clinical and radiological findings. PFS measures are often reported as time to progression (TTP) or progression-free survival (PFS) rates. In some cases, progression-free risk/proportions may be presented. However, there is some confusion between PFS, TTP, disease-free survival (DFS), disease-progression-free survival (DPFS), time to progression (TTP), and time to first event (TFE). PFS and overall survival (OS) are usually presented as Kaplan-Meier curves, and hazard ratios may be calculated (long-rank test) to compare the treatment groups. If radiological response data are available, objective response rates (ORR) and disease control rates (DCR) should also be presented. Objective response rate is defined as the percentage of patients whose best response during follow-up is complete or partial response. The DCR is an umbrella term for two similar measures: disease control rate (DCR), which is the percentage of patients whose best response during follow-up is complete response, CR; partial response, PR; or stable disease, SD.

Mean arterial pressure (MAP) will provide insights into the patient's hemodynamic stability during the recruitment maneuver and general anesthesia. It can be calculated using the formula (SBP + 2*DBP) / 3, where SBP is systolic blood pressure and DBP is diastolic blood pressure. Monitoring MAP will help assess the cardiovascular response and any potential adverse effects. Additionally, assessing arterial blood oxygen levels through arterial blood gas analysis will provide information on the patient's oxygenation status during mechanical ventilation. Cmax represents the highest drug concentration (maximum) measured until the time point measured.
