We should include the characterization of the area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201, as well as the characterization of the maximum concentration (Cmax), time to maximum concentration (Tmax), and pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201. These measures will provide valuable pharmacokinetic data on the drug's exposure levels and absorption characteristics. Additionally, we should consider measures such as objective response rate (ORR), duration of response (iDoR), clinical benefit rate (iCBR), progression-free survival (iPFS), and incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201. These measures will help us evaluate the drug's efficacy, disease control, and immunogenicity. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for each secondary outcome measure:

1. Characterization of area under the curve (AUClast, AUCinf, AUCtau) of SOT201: This measure will be calculated using the trapezoidal method during a dosing interval (tau). We will assess AUC values from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

2. Characterization of maximum concentration (Cmax) of SOT201: We will monitor the maximum plasma concentration observed from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17.) until cycle 20.

3. Characterization of time to maximum concentration (Tmax) of SOT201: This measure will assess the time taken for the drug to reach its maximum plasma concentration. We will evaluate Tmax from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

4. Characterization of pre-dose concentration (Ctrough) of SOT201: We will measure the pre-dose trough SOT201 concentrations from Day 1 of Cycle 1 to Cycle 3, and then from cycle 4 every other cycle (4, 6, 8), and from cycle 8 at quarterly frequency (11, 14, 17..) until cycle 20.

5. Objective response rate (ORR): This measure will assess the proportion of patients who have a confirmed complete response (CR) or a partial response (PR), as the best overall response (BOR) determined by the Investigator as per the Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumors (RECIST) v1.1. We will evaluate ORR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

6. Duration of response (iDoR): iDoR is defined as the time from the first documented evidence of confirmed CR or PR until progressive disease (PD) determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iDoR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted up to approximately 3 years.

7. Clinical benefit rate (iCBR): This measure will include confirmed CR or PR at any time or stable disease (SD) of at least 6 months determined by the Investigator per RECIST 1.1. We will evaluate iCBR from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

8. Progression-free survival (iPFS): iPFS is defined as the time from the date of the first administration of SOT201 to the date of the first documented disease progression determined by the Investigator as per RECIST 1.1 or death from any cause, whichever occurs first. We will assess iPFS from Day 1 of Cycle 1 until disease progression or the start of new anticancer therapy, whichever comes first. The assessment will be conducted for up to approximately 3 years.

9. Incidence of anti-drug antibodies (ADAs) against SOT201: We will assess the incidence of patients with anti-drug antibodies from Day 1 until 30 (±2) days after the last dose of SOT201.

The dysbiosis index (DI) is a mathematical tool developed by Chen et al.1 to quantify gut dysbiosis. This tool uses clinical microbiological data, including the abundance of 62 bacterial genera that are known to be associated with dysbiosis and their respective healthy reference ranges. The algorithm calculates a subject's DI score by estimating the number of bacterial genera outside the healthy reference range in their gut microbiome. Higher DI scores indicate a higher degree of gut dysbiosis. In this case, assessing the change in DI scores before and after fecal microbiota transplantation could help to quantify the magnitude of improvement in gut dysbiosis with FMT treatment. Please note that a specific software called “Dysbiosis_Calculator” is needed to calculate the DI scores.

A decrease in the total score by ≥50 points is considered a clinically significant response, indicating improvement in IBS symptoms. It would be ideal to assess this outcome measure at the baseline and at the end point of the trial, which in this case would be 12 months after FMT. This timeframe allows for a comprehensive evaluation of the long-term effects of fecal microbiota transplantation on IBS symptoms.

The dysbiosis index is a 5-scale index that measures the imbalance in gut microbiota composition. A DI above 2 indicates a microbiota profile that differs significantly from a normobiotic reference collection. Higher values on the index indicate more severe dysbiosis. Assessing the dysbiosis index at the 12-month mark after FMT would provide valuable insights into the impact of fecal microbiota transplantation on restoring a healthy gut microbiota composition in patients with IBS.

model_response: For secondary outcome measures, we will include the overall response rate (ORR) according to ELN 2022 criteria. The ORR is a composite outcome measure comprising both CR and CRi. Additionally, the early and the overall treatment efficacy will be assessed by the changes in the bone marrow blasts, peripheral blood counts, and flow cytometry before and after the treatment. The clinical and laboratory features will be described using the proportion of patients with different clinical and laboratory variables. A time-dependent relapse will be analyzed using the Kaplan-Meier method, while the time-independent relapse will be analyzed using the chi-square test. Finally, the safety profile of DASATINIB will be evaluated through the hematology, biochemistry, and nonhematology adverse events. Does that make sense to you?

Certainly! Let's start with response rates. These secondary measures will assess the rate of partial remission (PR) and rates of partial remission with incomplete hematologic recovery (PRi) according to ELN 2022 criteria at 2 months. The time to response will provide the percentage of patients who achieve (CR/PR/PRi) within 2 to 6 months, and duration of relapse-free period will capture the continuous duration of no recurrence following CR. Event-free survival will be the time-to-event that reflects whether the patient experiences disease progression or not. Finally, overall survival, a time variable assessing the amount of time a patient survives starting from diagnosis, will be captured. How does that sound?

The time to response would measure the time from the start of treatment with DASATINIB to the first response according to ELN 2022 criteria. The duration of this measure would be 3 months, with the start of treatment being a day (d) 29 and first response assessment being a d 57 of treatment.

The duration of the relapse-free period measure tracks how long patients maintain the response after CR, CRi, or PR. This measure will not be measured for the first 3 months of treatment (start of treatment to first response), as patients will not already have achieved a response. To allow enough time for the disease to recur, we will measure the relapse-free period over an 18-month time frame after the completion of phase 1.

The event-free survival measure assesses the time until patients experience disease progression or death (whichever happens first), without experiencing any other events such as significant toxicity. This measure will be evaluated over a time frame of 2 months.

Overall survival measures the survival of patients from the start of treatment to the time of death due to any reason. This measure assesses how effective DASATINIB treatment is in improving patient survival. Considering that patients are enrolled in this trial in the refractory stage, the relevant time frame for this measure would be 3 months.

The occurrence of adverse events is an important measure to assess the safety of DASATINIB monotherapy. This measure evaluates the rate at which adverse events occur, such as neutropenia, thrombocytopenia, liver function changes, and anemia, among others. The collection of this measure will continue throughout the entire 3 months of the treatment period. The time frame for collecting data for this measure will be 3 months.

The duration of the relapse-free period measure assesses how long patients can remain free from disease recurrence after responding to treatment. Event-free survival is an important measure for assessing the overall impact of DASATINIB monotherapy on patient outcomes. It includes relapse, lack of response, or death. This measure provides a comprehensive view of treatment efficacy beyond just the response rates. The time frame for event-free survival will also be 3 months.

The overall survival measure focuses on the duration of survival from the start of treatment. It provides essential information on the impact of DASATINIB monotherapy on patient survival outcomes. groundtruth: For the secondary outcome measures, we can consider several factors. One important aspect is evaluating the efficacy of CM313/Placebo treatment at each visit period. This would involve assessing the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 30 × 10^9/L and at least twice the baseline platelet count without bleeding at each visit period after initial administration. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks to capture the treatment efficacy over a longer duration. What are your thoughts on this?

Absolutely! Another important measure could be the evaluation of the complete remission rate after CM313/Placebo treatment at each visit period. This measure would determine the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 100 × 10^9/L without bleeding at each visit period. It provides valuable information on the achievement of complete remission, which is a critical goal in the treatment of immune thrombocytopenia. The time frame for this measure would also be 24 weeks. What do you think of this measure?

Yes, there are a few more secondary outcome measures we can include. One is the proportion of subjects with a platelet count ≥ 50 × 10^9/L at each visit period. This measure focuses on maintaining a safe platelet level and preventing bleeding episodes. Additionally, we can consider measures such as "Time to response (TTR)," "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥30×10^9/L," "Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥50×10^9/L," "Emergency treatment," "Concomitant maintenance drug," "Number of subjects with clinically significant bleeding," and "Adverse events assessment." Each of these measures provides valuable insights into the efficacy, safety, and impact of CM313 treatment. Would you like more details on any of these measures?

Certainly! Here are the details:

- Time to response (TTR): This measure assesses the time needed from treatment initiation to a platelet count ≥30×10^9/L and at least twice the baseline platelet count. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥30×10^9/L: This measure evaluates the cumulative weeks of platelet count ≥30×10^9/L without any platelet elevating therapy or dose increment of TPO-RA and/or corticosteroids. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Cumulative weeks of platelet ≥50×10^9/L: Similar to the previous measure, this assesses the cumulative weeks of platelet count ≥50×10^9/L without any platelet elevating therapy or dose increment of TPO-RA and/or corticosteroids. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

- Emergency treatment: This measure determines the percentage of patients who require emergency treatment after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would also be 24 weeks.

- Concomitant maintenance drug: This measure focuses on changes in concomitant maintenance therapy at week 12 compared to before CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 12 weeks.

- Number of subjects with clinically significant bleeding: This measure assesses changes in the number of subjects based on the World Health Organization (WHO) bleeding score after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 12 weeks.

- Adverse events assessment: This measure evaluates the incidence, severity, and relationship of treatment emergent adverse events after CM313/Placebo treatment. The time frame for this measure would be 24 weeks.

groundtruth:
Certainly! Here are the details for each primary outcome measure:

1. Arterial thickness: This will be measured by carotid ultrasound intimal media thickness and reported in millimeters. It will be assessed at the baseline.

2. Arterial stiffness: We will measure arterial stiffness using carotid ultrasound pulse wave velocity and report it in meters per second. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

3. Baroreflex sensitivity: The slope between heart rate and blood pressure at rest and during the Valsalva Maneuver will be measured in milliseconds per millimeter of mercury. This measure will be assessed at the baseline.

4. Sympathetic response to stress: We will evaluate the blood pressure or muscle sympathetic nerve activity response to sympathoexcitatory stressors, reporting it in millimeters of mercury or bursts per minute. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend focusing on arterial elasticity, neurovascular function, and ankle-brachial index. These measures will provide valuable insights into the structural and functional aspects of the arteries, as well as the impact of sympathetic function on peripheral circulation. What are your thoughts on these suggestions?

Certainly! Here are the details for the secondary outcome measures:

1. Arterial elasticity: This will be measured using elastography and reported in kilopascals. It will be assessed at the baseline.

2. Neurovascular function: We will evaluate neurovascular function through microneurography, reporting the activity in bursts per minute. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

3. Ankle-brachial index: Using Doppler ultrasound, we will measure the ankle-brachial index, which will be reported as a ratio. This measure will also be assessed at the baseline.

Certainly! Here are the outcome measures we have designed:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Shunt fraction value: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter shunt fraction value found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Pulmonary blood flow - trend: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter PBF trend found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.
- Functional residual capacity - trend: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter FRC trend found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.
- Pulmonary blood flow - absolute value: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter PBF absolute values found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.
- Functional residual capacity - absolute value: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter FRC absolute values found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.
- Physiological dead space: Confirming the performance of non-invasive pulmonary health parameter physiological dead space value found on the VQm PHM™ monitor when compared to available reference measurements. The time frame for this measure is through study completion, an average of 12 months.

Safety Measures:
- Oxygen desaturation due to breathing circuit connectivity: Number of participants with treatment-related adverse events due to faulty connecting the breathing circuit during normal operation of the VQm PHM™ monitor as measured by oxygen saturation desaturations of SpO2 <89% for >14s. The time frame for this measure is through completion of the study, up to 72 hours.
- High pressure due to volume control: Number of participants with device-related adverse events due to increased pressure induced by volume-control mode as determined by peak pressure >10cm H2O ventilator setting. The time frame for this measure is through completion of the study, up to 72 hours.
- High volume due to pressure control: Number of participants with device-related adverse events due to increased volume induced by pressure-control mode as determined by a volume >200mL from the target volume. The time frame for this measure is through completion of the study, up to 72 hours.
- Safe range of nitrous oxide delivery: Confirming the acceptable safety limitations of nitrous oxide gas delivery by the VQm PHM™ monitor below 10% as measured by the device. The time frame for this measure is through completion of the study, up to 72 hours.
- Incident rate of adverse events, adverse events, and treatment-emergent serious adverse events: As deemed caused by the VQm PHM™ monitor during standard of care in the ICU setting. The time frame for this measure is through completion of the study, up to 72 hours.

model_response: Okay. Regarding the aim of the trial, could you please summarize it in one sentence? This will help to ensure that I have a clear understanding of what it is you would like me to assist you with.

There are several methods that are commonly used to measure the power output of lower limb muscles, such as dynamometers, hand-held devices, force plates, and isokinetic dynamometers. Each method has its pros and cons, so it depends on the specific requirements of your trial. For example, hand-held devices are portable and easy to use, but have a limitation on the load they can apply. Force plates can provide good accuracy but are affected by the position of the participant. Dynamometers are more accurate and have the advantage of allowing participants to perform knee flexion. They are also popular instruments in rehabilitation studies. Isokinetic dynamometers provide the best accuracy but also have the highest cost. In the context of your clinical trial, dynamometers and isokinetic dynamometers may be the best options to measure the power output of the knee extensors and flexors, as they can provide accurate and consistent measurements. Additionally, isokinetic dynamometers can allow participants to perform knee flexion and provide isokinetic testing. When choosing a measurement device, it would also be helpful to consider the study population and their muscle strength levels. For instance, isokinetic dynamometers are suitable for both the frail and fit population, while dynamometers with adjustable seat height and back rest are more suitable for frail participants with low strength levels.

Yes, we can include muscle strength as one of the secondary outcome measures. We can measure this using the quadriceps peak torque obtained from isokinetic dynamometry. A higher peak torque value in newton metallers (Nm) indicates greater muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at different time points: preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

For measuring mobility, we suggest using the modified Timed Up and Go test. This test will be conducted in three different trial conditions. 1) At rest to stand up from a chair; 2) at the stand-up state of the Timed Up and Go test; and 3) walking away from a given position after the change of position from 1) to 2) and returning to the given position. Participants start in a standard chair with a backrest, with a seat height of 50 cm. They'll be asked to stand up from a sitting position with arms folded across the chest, walk for three meters, turn, walk back three meters, and sit down by crossing the arms over the chest. We'll measure the time it takes the patient to perform the tasks from start to end, with the starting time given when the participant moves their hands from the chest and stops the timer when both feet are positioned on the walking track. We do not allow the patient to use walking aids. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge, 6 week and 12 weeks postoperative time points.

To measure clinical results, we can use the Knee Injury and Osteoarthritis Outcome Score (KOOS). This 5-item knee pain questionnaire is a validated assessing tool that can provide patient-reported outcome measures (PROMS) following total knee arthroplasty. It comprises patients' self-assessments of pain, symptoms, ADL function, sports and recreation function, and knee-related quality of life. Higher values indicate better functional outcomes. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

Radiological results can be measured using x-rays. The x-rays that can be used include anteroposterior and lateral full-length standing x-rays. These x-rays will provide information on the alignment of the femur and tibia and will help assess the integrity of the joint surfaces, hardware, stem lengths, and stem alignments. The imaging can be assessed preoperatively, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on using x-rays for measurement?

To assess pain control, we can use a visual analog pain scale (0-10). We'll ask the patient, in resting conditions, to rate the intensity of their knee pain during activities of daily living and during physical examination. This pain score will be assessed at postoperative days 1, 2, and 3, as well as at discharge, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. The pain score will also be reassessed immediately and 5 and 10 minutes after the nerve block wears off. Lower pain scores indicate better pain control. Additionally, we can use the opioid medication doses the patient has taken. In that regard, we can also measure the total oral morphine equivalents (OMEs) as a quantitative indicator of pain perception and can be used as an indirect measure of pain control. We can assess this outcome at postoperative days 1, 2, and 3, as well as at discharge, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this?

To document opioid consumption, we can keep a record of the total morphine milligram equivalent (MME) in grams, administered in-hospital and after discharge during each time point. This approach will help assess how different anesthesia methods affect opioid consumption after surgery. We can assess opioid consumption at preoperative, 6 hours, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach for opioid consumption?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can keep a record of the total hours or days in the hospital, including from the admission until the day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative). We can also add a section for any re-admissions or any change in discharge status. What do you think about this approach?

To measure patient satisfaction, we can use a standardized Likert scale. The 7-point scale can vary from 1, indicating "extremely satisfied," to 7, indicating "extremely dissatisfied." We can assess patient satisfaction on day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative) and 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

Lastly, we can assess patient follow-up. To achieve this, we will schedule follow-up appointments with each participant. We will assess the various outcome measures as described previously: 6 weeks after surgery, 12 weeks after surgery, and 1 year after surgery. If the patients are unavailable for participation in a particular session, we will give them a window of 2-3 weeks during the follow-up period to keep the one-year data collection window intact. What do you think about this approach to follow-up?

You're very welcome! I'm glad to have been able to help. If you have any other questions or need further clarifications regarding the outcome measures or the clinical trial protocol, don't hesitate to ask! I'm here to help. Good luck with the trial!
groundtruth: Thank you for clarifying. Now, let's move on to the outcome measures. We'll start with the primary outcome measure. Do you have any specific outcome in mind that you would like to measure?

That's a great choice for a primary outcome measure. To measure the functional muscle power output of the leg, we can use the cycle sprint test. This test measures the maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts from three times 10-second maximal efforts. Higher values indicate better muscle power output. We can assess this outcome measure at different time points: preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

Absolutely! For measuring muscle strength, we can use the manual muscle testing (MMT) as a standardized measuring tool. The patient, in a sitting position with 20 degrees knee flexion, will be asked to actively extend the knee against resistance proximal to the ankle. We'll use the numeric score 0-5 from the Daniels and Worthingham Scale to assess quadriceps muscle strength. Higher values indicate better muscle strength. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To measure mobility, we can use the timed up and go test (TUG). This test is a standardized measuring tool that times the patient's ability to rise from an armchair, walk to a line on the floor 3 meters away, turn, and walk back to the chair. Lower values on the TUG test indicate better mobility. We can assess this outcome measure at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think?

For clinical results, we can include parameters such as redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. These parameters will provide a comprehensive evaluation of the clinical outcomes and potential complications associated with the surgery and nerve blocks. We can assess these clinical results at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this?

To assess radiological results, we can use x-rays, including ap and lateral views, patella views, and whole leg axis views. These x-rays will help us evaluate the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. We can assess radiological results at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To measure pain control, we can use the numeric rating scale (NRS) ranging from 0 to 10, with lower values indicating better pain control. We can assess pain levels before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this measurement for pain control?

To document opioid consumption, we can keep a record of the administered drugs, including the name of the drug, dosage, and frequency of use. This documentation will help us evaluate the patterns of opioid consumption before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

To document the length of hospital stay, we can simply keep a record of the number of days the patient spends in the hospital. This will help us evaluate the duration of the hospital stay before surgery, during the hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What are your thoughts on this approach?

For patient satisfaction, we can use two questionnaires: the Oxford Knee Score and EQ-5D-5L. The Oxford Knee Score is a questionnaire with a range of 12-60 points, with lower values indicating better satisfaction. The EQ-5D-5L questionnaire consists of 5 questions with 5 answers each, including EQ-VAS, which ranges from 0 to 100, with higher values indicating better satisfaction. We can assess patient satisfaction at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery. What do you think about this approach?

Great! Here are the full outcome measures for the clinical trial:

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Functional muscle power output of the leg: Cycle sprint test measuring maximum lower limb muscle power in Watts (W) from 3 times 10-second maximal efforts. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Muscle strength: Manual muscle testing (MMT) using a numeric score 0-5 (Daniels and Worthingham Scale) to assess quadriceps muscle strength. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Mobility: Timed up and go test (TUG) to assess mobility. This will be assessed at preoperative, 48 hours after surgery, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Clinical results: Including redness, swelling, hyperthermia, wound/scar assessment, range of motion, stability, and adverse events. This will be assessed at preoperative, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Radiological results: X-rays to assess the alignment of the leg, patella position, and overall leg axis. This will be assessed at preoperative, day 1 after surgery, 6 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Pain control: Numeric rating scale 0-10 to assess pain levels. This will be assessed before surgery, twice daily on the ward (except for the first 6 hours: hourly), day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Opioid consumption: Documentation of administered drugs, including name, dosage, and frequency of use. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Length of hospital stay: Documentation of the number of days in the hospital. This will be assessed before surgery, during hospital stay, day of discharge (7+/- 2 days postoperative), 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 1: Questionnaire (Oxford Knee Score) with a range of 12-60 points. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
- Patient satisfaction 2: Questionnaire (EQ-5D-5L) with 5 questions and EQ-VAS ranging from 0 to 100. This will be assessed at preoperative, 6 weeks, 12 weeks, and 1 year after surgery.
You're welcome! I'm glad I could help. If you have any more questions or need further assistance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your trial!

model_response: There isn't a "one size fits all" rule for determining the time frame for assessing OR. The time frame is usually selected based on the rate of change of the disease progression, which can vary depending on the specific cancer and treatment regimen used. In order to assess OR, there must be sufficient time to observe the response to treatment, and enough time between disease progression to allow discrimination between response and progression. As a general guideline, in order to distinguish response from progression, a time period of 3 months (9 weeks) is recommended, regardless of whether the study was placebo-controlled or non-randomized, based on tumor assessments by the RECIST (v1.1).

For secondary outcome measures, please provide the study period, number of participants expected to have data, and if the measure is continuous or binary. You have 180 participants expected to have data, which is less than or equal to 50% of the participants.

Progression-Free Survival (PFS) is defined as the time from the date of first treatment to the date of documented progression or death due to any cause, whichever occurs first. This measure is used to assess the effectiveness of the treatment in controlling tumor growth and progression.

The median PFS, estimated by the Kaplan–Meier method, can be assessed from the start of treatment until the date of progression as determined by RECIST v1.1 criteria or death at any time, whichever occurs first. This way, the median PFS can be accurately determined from the data set even if there are cases of ongoing response and cases where the data were censored at the last follow-up time.

Another commonly used secondary outcome measure is Overall Survival (OS). It can be defined as the time from the date of first treatment administration to the date of death from any cause, or to the last available follow-up. Does that sound appropriate?

The measure description for Overall Survival (OS) can be defined as the time from the date of first treatment until death from any cause. This measure helps us evaluate the impact of treatment on long-term patient survival and provides general information on the disease condition without being directly associated with the treatment regimen.

A suitable time frame for assessing Overall Survival (OS) is the overall survival rate one year after the start of treatment. By evaluating OS at this time point, it allows for a meaningful comparison to standard chemotherapy regimens and provides valuable information on the long-term benefits of the treatment regimen.

Certainly. We have chosen Overall Response (OR) (CR + PR) according to the independent central review using Response Evaluation Criteria in Solid Tumours (RECIST) v1.1 as the primary outcome measure for the study. The secondary outcome measures consist of Progression-Free Survival (PFS) through the end of the study treatment, which is approximately 16 months after the study start, and Overall Survival (OS) through the end of the study follow-up, which is approximately 32 months after the study start. These outcome measures will help evaluate the anti-tumor activity and durability of the treatment response, as well as the survival benefits over extended periods. Does this summary sound accurate?
You're very welcome! I'm glad I could help. If you have any further questions or need more guidance in the future, feel free to ask. Good luck with your outcome measures and clinical trial!

model_response: We could include two outcome measures for patients and another set for caregivers. The first two measures could be the CBI, which is a self-reported measure indicating patient satisfaction with their relationship with their caregiver. It is an eight-item scale, and the items are answered on a five-point Likert scale, with a higher score indicating that the relationship between the patient and caregiver is more satisfactory. This measure has been previously used in a study to assess the effectiveness of a family-based intervention promoting psychological empowerment to caregivers of persons with Alzheimer's disease . The second measure for patients could be a self-reported measure of caregiver burden. We can use three items from the Dementia Caregiver Burden Scale (DCBS) to calculate a summary score for caregiver burden, including the following items: I was unhappy with the increased responsibility of caring for the person with dementia, I was unhappy with my difficulties managing the daily tasks of caring for the person with dementia, and I felt overwhelmed by the level of care given to the person with dementia [24, 25].

The secondary outcomes can be divided into two categories: those that evaluate patient/caregiver outcomes immediately following discharge from a skilled nursing facility and those that assess the effect of the Connect-Home Plus intervention on preventing or delaying rehospitalization. Would that be accurate?

Certainly! The preparedness for discharge will be assessed using a 12-item interview guide with questions related to the support received from your facility staff member, concerns/challenges associated with the transition, and suggestions for others. We can generate 4-point Likert scale scores to indicate how prepared the participants feel before, immediately after arrival at their home, and 30 days after the arrival for discharge.

For the caregiver's preparedness for caregiving, we can use a similar approach. We can use the Readiness for Caregiving Questionnaire from Wan et al., which measures three aspects of readiness for caregiving. It assesses preparedness through five 5-point Likert-type statements that include: "I feel ready," "I have the necessary knowledge," "I have the necessary skills," "I have help from others when I need it," and "I have the support I need from others." Higher scores indicate better preparedness for caregiving. Would you like to use this instrument?

For the patient's functioning, we can use two self-report questionnaires, the Barthel Index and the Patient-Generated Subjective Global Questionnaire (PG-SGP). The Barthel Index has 10 items on a dichotomous (yes-no) scale and measures the patient's ability to perform activities of daily living. The higher the score, the greater the level of independence. The PG-SGP has one item that the patient rates their overall function compared to one year prior. The scores can range from zero to five (zero to one if the patient cannot compare their function to one year prior). We can use both of these measures to provide a comprehensive assessment of the patient's functional ability after discharge.

To assess caregiver burden, we can use the Caregiver Strain Index, which includes 4 sub-scales. These sub-scales measure emotional, psychological, physical, and financial strain. Each sub-scale includes 10 items on a 0- to 10-point scale. Higher scores indicate greater burden. To assess caregiver distress, we can use the Caregiver Health Questionnaire, which has 19 items rated on a 4-point scale. Higher scores suggest greater distress. These measures will help evaluate the impact of the intervention on the caregiver's well-being and burden. How does that sound?
You're welcome! I'm glad I could be of help. If you have any more questions, don't hesitate to ask. Good luck with your study!
groundtruth: To assess patient satisfaction, we can use an interview guide with questions about the factors that made the Connect-Home Plus transitional care services easy or difficult to use, specific supports that were and were not helpful, and the overall impact on managing issues related to Alzheimer's disease and other dementias at home. The interview guide can generate 4-point Likert scale acceptability scores. As for caregiver satisfaction, we can use a similar interview guide to assess their experience with the intervention. How does that sound?

Based on the goals of your study, it would be beneficial to assess the patient's preparedness for discharge, their functional ability, and their quality of life. Additionally, we should also evaluate caregiver burden and distress. Would you like me to provide more details on these outcome measures?

Sure! Let's start with the patient's preparedness for discharge. We can use the Care Transitions Measure-15 (CTM-15), which includes 15 items on a 4-point scale. This measure assesses the patient's self-reported knowledge and skills for continuing care at home. Higher scores on the CTM-15 indicate greater preparedness for discharge. Does that make sense?

To assess the caregiver's preparedness, we can use the Preparedness for Caregiving Scale (PCS). It includes 8 items on a five-point Likert scale and measures the caregiver's self-reported readiness for caregiving. Higher scores on the PCS indicate greater preparedness. This measure will provide insights into the caregiver's confidence and ability to provide care to the patient at home. How does that sound?

For the patient's function, we can use the Life Space Assessment, which measures mobility and independence. It includes Likert scales corresponding to levels of mobility and independence, with lower scores indicating less life-space. This measure provides insights into the patient's ability to engage in daily activities and navigate their environment. As for the patient's quality of life, we can use the Dementia Quality of Life Measure, which assesses various dimensions of quality of life. It has 28 items and higher scores indicate better quality of life. These measures will help evaluate the impact of the intervention on the patient's overall well-being. Does that answer your question?

To measure caregiver burden, we can use the Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale. It includes 12 items on a five-point scale and measures the caregiver's perceptions of the adverse effects of caregiving on their emotional, social, financial, physical, and spiritual functioning. Higher scores on the Zarit Caregiver Burden Scale indicate greater burden. For caregiver distress, we can use the Distress Thermometer, which includes one item on an 11-point scale measuring negative affect related to caregiving. Scores above 4 on the Distress Thermometer indicate distress. These measures will help assess the impact of caregiving on the caregiver's well-being. Does that clarify the assessment of caregiver burden and distress?

You're welcome! I'm glad I could assist you in designing the outcome measures for your study. If you have any more questions or need further guidance, feel free to ask. Good luck with your clinical trial!

Certainly! Here are the measure descriptions and time frames for the secondary outcome measures:

- Progression-free survival (PFS): PFS is defined as the time from the date the participant started study drug to the date the participant experiences an event of disease progression or death. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Duration of Response (DOR): DOR is defined as the time from the date of first documented CR or PR, assessed by the investigator and based on RECIST v. 1.1, to the documented date of progressive disease (PD) or death, whichever occurred first. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Time to Response (TTR): TTR is defined as the time from the first dose to the first documented CR or PR, which is subsequently confirmed. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Overall Survival (OS): OS is defined as the time from the date the participant started study drug to death for any reason. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Clinical Benefit Rate (CBR): CBR is defined as the percentage of participants with a confirmed complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) or a stable disease (SD) of 8 weeks or longer based on RECIST version 1.1. The time frame for this measure would be 1 year.

- Number of Participants with Adverse Events: This measure assesses the occurrence of any untoward medical events in the participants. The time frame for this measure would be 2 years.

- Various pharmacokinetic measures: These measures include maximum observed plasma concentration (Cmax), time to maximum observed plasma concentration (Tmax), observed trough concentration (Ctrough), and area under the plasma concentration-time curve (AUC) for NKT2152, palbociclib, and sasanlimab. The time frame for these measures would be 1 year.

These secondary outcome measures will provide valuable insights into various aspects of the treatment's efficacy, safety, and pharmacokinetics. Are you satisfied with these measures?

Objective sleep quality measures are essential to complement subjective measures. Actigraphy is a valid objective approach to measuring sleep quality. Actigraphs are often used in sleep studies, and they can provide information on sleep-wake cycles, sleep duration, and sleep efficiency. Polysomnography (PSG) is a more comprehensive and highly quantifiable analysis of sleep quality compared to actigraphy: it involves data from multiple sources such as heart rate, airflow, and muscle activity, as well as measurements of a person's overall body movements throughout the night. The objective sleep measures may be to use the Sleep Sense 3.0 Actigraphy Diary and polysomnography (PSG).

Assessments of objective sleep quality measures ought to be made throughout the perioperative period; they can be assessed before, during, and after surgery. Assessments of total sleep time, sleep efficiency, and sleep latency can be made based on the activity-time logs that the patients complete. Wake-up time after falling asleep can be assessed using wristwatches with an actigraphy function. These devices measure movement and analyze it to determine whether a person is resting or active.

It's crucial to assess acute pain intensity as an outcome measure. To reduce the variability in pain assessment, I suggest using a validated measure such as the Numerical Pain Rating Scale (NPRS). The NPRS is a patient-friendly, quick, and easy-to-use method for assessing pain intensity on a scale of 0 to 10, with 0 being no pain and 10 being the worst pain possible. It's preferable to use this scale rather than a numeric scale that has not been shown to be reliable.

Additionally, it includes a global score that encompasses the entire night's sleep. The PSQI helps evaluate overall sleep quality and enables the identification of sleep disorders.

The body weight and body height of the participants will be measured using a balance beam scale and stadiometer, respectively, at baseline; after 2 weeks of treatment; and after 4 weeks of treatment. We will use the BMI as a measure to assess the severity of obesity in diabetic patients. All these measures will give us an estimate of the weight loss or body weight gain that occurs in the participants after treatment with Canagliflozin and serve as another reference for whether the severity of fatty liver is changed in the participants.

The measurement of BMI before and after treatment will be conducted at screening, baseline, and 12-week visits. To calculate BMI, we will take into account each patient's body height and weight with minimal clothing and without shoes. The values will then be rounded up to the nearest tenth of a kilogram for body weight and the nearest millimeter for body height. To calculate BMI, we will divide the patient's body weight (in kilograms) by the square of their body height (in meters). This is a well-recognized measure of obesity. model_response: Yes, the first secondary outcome measure is the terminal half-life of NNC0194-0499 after a single dose. It is measured in hours (h). Half-life is a pharmacokinetic parameter that indicates the time required for a substance to be metabolized and eliminated from the body. A longer half-life could reflect a longer duration of action, but it could also be a sign of slow clearance or accumulation.

Precisely! This is one of the critical measures that tells us how quickly the drug is absorbed and distributed in your body. It helps assess the early distribution phase of NNC0194-0499 in your serum.

Other secondary outcome measures include NNC0194-0499 concentrations at specific time points: Ctrough,0499,T,SD (measured at Visit 9 between 03.00 and 06.00 h on Day 36 (end of treatment, trough at 03.00–06.00 h)), C3h,0499,SD (measured at Visit 9, 3 h after NNC0194-0499 administration, trough at 06.00 h), C4h,0499,SD (measured at Visit 9, 4 h after NNC0194-0499 administration, trough at 09.00 h), Ct4,0499,T,SD (measured at Visit 9, between 09.00 and 12.00 h, post-dose on Day 36, trough C at 09.00–12.00 h). These measures give us an understanding of the minimum concentration of the drug at different time points in your serum, helping us evaluate the accumulation of the drug and its clearance.
Exactly! It provides insights into the rate of absorption of the drug in your body and the time required to reach its peak concentration.

Another secondary outcome is AUC0-∞,SD, which represents the area under the serum concentration-time curve from the time of dosing until infinity. It is measured in hours multiplied by nanomoles per liter (h*nmol/L). This measure provides insights into how well the drug is absorbed and eliminated from your body. The time frame for measuring this outcome is the same as the primary outcome measure.

Exactly! They help us determine the amount of time the drug remains in the body (half-life), the amount of the drug in the body after it reaches a steady level in the blood (volume of distribution), the amount of the drug eliminated from the body after reaching a steady level in the blood (clearance), and the fraction of the drug eliminated from the body via the kidneys (renal clearance). These measures are important for understanding the pharmacokinetics and dosing of the drug.

Alright. Based on the information you provided, I suggest considering the following primary outcome measures:

1. Adherence Performance: This measure aims to evaluate the adherence performance of the OBI device on the arm over 28 hours of wear under normal daily activities in healthy human subjects, with and without the use of an additional adhesive ring. The measure includes assessing the adhesive integrity at the end of device wear by evaluating the adherence of the adhesive pad to the participant's skin. This can be measured using a scale ranging from 0 to 4, where 0 indicates full adherence and 4 indicates full detachment. The assessment will be conducted during the wear period of 28 hours.

The time frame for assessing the adherence performance would be during the 28-hour wear period of the device. This allows us to evaluate the durability of the adhesive and its ability to keep the device in place over an extended period of time.

For secondary outcome measures, I suggest considering the following:

1. Skin effects: This measure aims to assess the cutaneous tissue effects associated with wearing the OBI device, with and without the additional adhesive ring. The assessment includes evaluating the presence of erythema, wheal, bleeding, bruising, and induration following device removal. The assessment can be done using specific tissue effects scales. Wheal, erythema, and bleeding can be graded on a scale from 0 (absence of event) to 4 (most severe presence of event), while bruising and induration can be reported as present or not. The assessment should be conducted upon device removal, as well as at 30 minutes and 2 hours after device removal.

8. Postoperative complication: This measures the occurrence of common postoperative complications such as pneumonia or urinary tract infections, with a binary response of yes or no. It will be assessed up to 18 weeks after the operation.

model_response: Glad to provide more information about the 6MWT! The 6MWT is a submaximal exercise test and measures the distance (in meters) an individual can walk on a flat, hard surface in six minutes . The test has been widely employed in patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease, asthma, and cystic fibrosis, as well as in patients with chronic heart failure. The 6MWT has excellent reliability, reproducibility, and ability to detect clinically significant changes in pulmonary [27–29] and exercise tolerance . For a more detailed description of the testing protocol, please see guidelines from the American Thoracic Society (https://www.thoracic.org/guidelines/details.php?guidelines=679). Have any additional questions about this outcome measure?

For secondary outcome measures, we suggest including self-efficacy, quality of life, exercise capacity, and functional status as multiple outcome measures. Self-efficacy is the perceived ability to perform specific behaviors that contribute to achieving a desired outcome or overcoming an obstacle. For the heart failure population, self-efficacy is an important measure of self-management and self-efficacy interventions in heart failure that increase patients' ability to understand and perform self-care behaviors, and help mitigate rehospitalization rates. Quality of life measures capture a patient’s overall perception of health, including physical, mental, emotional, and/or social health. The Medical Outcomes Study (MOS) questionnaire is a commonly used health-related quality of life measure that is available in different versions including SF-12 and SF-36. Exercise capacity is the ability to perform physical fitness activities or functions of daily living. This outcome measure can be measured by cardiopulmonary exercise testing or clinical evaluations based on the exercise performed during a 6MWT using the modified Borg scale. Functional status assesses physical, cognitive, and psychosocial functioning, as well as the level of functional independence. The Katz Index and Activities of Daily Living (ADL) scales may function as outcome measures. Would these suggestions be helpful to you for your study?

The measure descriptions for the other secondary outcome measures are as follows:Oxygen saturation: this measure is obtained using a pulse oximeter that clips onto the individual's finger. It directly assesses peripheral oxygen saturation, which provides valuable information on the body's ability to transport oxygen to the tissues during physical activity. Hearts rate: this measure is calculated as the number of heartbeats per minute. It can be obtained using a pulse oximeter or an electrocardiogram (EKG) to directly assess the change in heart rate during the 6MWT. The modified Borg Scale: this scale provides a way to ask individuals to rate the perceived exertion they experienced during the 6MWT. It is a 15-point category scale that is simple to use and easy to understand. It ranges from level 6 (no exertion at all) to level 20 (maximum exertion.

To address this limitation, a CCI score based on administrative data has also been developed, but this approach may have the disadvantage of misclassification due to the absence of structured reports and variability in administrative data coding. Nonetheless, the physician-based CCI is considered a valuable measure for assessing complications in surgical trials.

model_response: Okay, observed outcomes are usually obtained through routine assessments during a specified period of time. For a trial with clinical endpoints, it's common to use a "time to event" analysis. For example, you may be interested in the time until a patient experiences a clinical event or the time until the patient reaches a particular outcome measure over several months. If you plan on having scheduled measurements at specific time points for your outcome, you could consider using a mixed-effects model with fixed effects for time and treatment and random effects for the intercept and baseline covariates. This type of model will allow you to analyze the data as repeated measures over time and adjust for confounding factors that may be related to a specific patient, such as age and gender. You can also account for the fact that patients may have different baseline levels of the outcome measure by including the baseline value as a covariate in the model. An alternative approach would be to use a linear mixed-effects model with fixed effects for time and treatment and random effects for the intercept and the error terms. This model will allow you to account for variation in the outcome measure that may be related to individual patients, as well as variation that may be related to other factors such as the timing of the outcome measure or the specific measurements used to assess the outcome.

Certainly, ∆E' is defined as the change in the velocity at the mitral E-wave before fluid resuscitation (E0) plus the velocity at the start of the infusion (E1) minus the velocity at the end of the infusion (E2) [∆E' = (E 0 – E 1) – E 2 ]. The use of E1 as a reference wave is important, as it has been observed that the mitral E-wave velocity (E0) often increases following an intravenous fluid challenge. Thus, ∆E' is designed to prevent bias and accurately assess the response to fluid resuscitation [30, 31]. The test is based on the principle that changes in tissue Doppler velocities (∆E') correspond to and can be used to predict changes in left ventricular stroke volume (∆SV) in response to volume status [22, 30]. It is well established that both measures are closely related in the presence of normal cardiac diastolic function.

For the secondary outcome measure, I recommend measuring the difference in LS diastolic tissue velocity (LS-DTT) of the mitral annulus at the inclusion time and after fluid administration. The measurement time after fluid administration will be determined based on the time when clinical response is noted. The goal is to understand the evolution of the diastolic function over time during an episode.

Certainly! Overall disease activity can be measured using either a composite score, such as the Behçet Activity Score (BAS) or Behçet Disease Activity Index (BDAI), or through clinical evaluation. The BAS is a standardized, validated tool that evaluates seven clinical manifestations, including oral ulcers, skin lesions, genital ulcers, articular disease, ophthalmological findings, and gastrointestinal and vascular involvement. The BDAI is another validated tool which assesses severity and duration of oral and genital ulcers, skin manifestations, and articular and ocular manifestations, and includes an assessment of lab values. For this clinical trial, we recommend using either the BAS or BDAI to monitor active disease. Clinical evaluation can be done through physical examination, patient history, evaluation of lab values such as inflammatory markers, and patient-reported information on the severity and duration of symptoms, including the number of recurrences.

Here's some more information about the outcome measures: Mini Nutritional Assessment-Short Form: The Mini Nutritional Assessment-Short Form (MNA-SF) is a brief screening tool that assesses the nutritional status of older adults. It consists of six items and covers three main areas: anthropometric measures, global assessment, and dietary intake. A higher score (5 points or more) indicates adequate nutritional status, while a score of three or less suggests malnutrition and a score of 4 indicates “malnutrition risk”. The MNA-SF has been validated and used extensively in home-based care, community settings, and other care contexts. It assesses both short-term and long-term nutritional prognoses, and it can also help identify cases of overnutrition [59, 60].Summary of Diabetes Self-Care Activities Measure (SDSCA): The Summary of Diabetes Self-Care Activities (SDSCA) is a structured questionnaire that assesses adherence to diabetes self-care by measuring various diabetes disease management behaviors, including diet, exercise, blood glucose monitoring, insulin use, and foot care. The SDSCA includes nine items: diet, exercise, satisfaction with diet, satisfaction with exercise, foot care, blood glucose testing, reporting blood glucose, insulin usage, and medication adherence. The items are rated on four- or six-level Likert scales based on the time or frequency of behavior. The response scale varies for each item. Some of the items are reverse-scored prior to calculating a normalized score. The SDSCA has good content validity and has been applied as a valid and reliable measure to evaluate the behavior of DM patients in a variety of settings, including hospital, public health, and patient education/support [61-63].Falls Efficacy Scale (FES): The FES assesses the level of personal concern of an individual in falling . model_response: In addition to the incidence of DLT, I suggest including another primary outcome measure that assesses the effectiveness of ND-003 in treating the underlying disease. This measure could be an objective response rate, defined as the proportion of patients who experience a tumor reduction, measured by clinical and/or radiologic assessments, regardless of the progression or regression of the disease. The objective response rate typically includes two key endpoints: the proportion of patients who experience disease regression, defined as at least a 30% reduction in the tumor in one dimension (a partial response); and the proportion of patients whose disease stabilizes, including the proportion of patients whose tumor reduction is small (no more than a 30% reduction in the tumor diameter, defined as stable disease) and the proportion of patients whose tumor increases slowly (defined as progressive disease).

Another primary outcome measure to consider is tumor growth inhibition. This measure will help evaluate the preliminary efficacy of the investigational product, ND-003, and provide an initial assessment of the potential anti-tumor activity. Tumor growth inhibition will be assessed by scanning the target lesion by CT scan 1 day before administration, post-one cycle of multiple administrations (28 days) and post administration at days 42, and 56. The target lesion will be the lesion with the best tumor response before the start of the treatment period, or if there is no response before the start of the treatment period, choose the largest lesion. These parameters will be measured as continuous (change from baseline) or categorical (best response) variables to assess the potential anticancer effects of ND-003. The continuous variables we can consider measuring include changes in tumor marker levels from baseline and changes in the sum of tumor dimensions from baseline. The categorical variables we can consider measuring include the overall response rate (ORR), which is the ratio of the number of patients with a best response of complete response (CR) or partial response (PR) to the total number of patients, and disease control rate (DCR), which is the ratio of the number of patients with a best response of CR, PR, or stable disease (SD) to the total number of patients.

groundtruth: Another important primary outcome measure to consider is the determination of the maximum tolerated dose (MTD) of ND-003. The MTD is defined as the highest dose level at which fewer than 1 out of 6 subjects experience DLT. This measure will help establish the appropriate dosing level for subsequent phases of the trial. The assessment for MTD will also occur 4 days after a single oral administration and the first cycle of multiple administrations (28 days). What are your thoughts on including MTD as a primary outcome measure?

Yes, one more primary outcome measure to consider is the assessment of adverse events (AE) using the CTCAE ver5.0. This measure involves monitoring and reporting treatment-related adverse events throughout the study. It will provide valuable information on the safety profile of ND-003. The assessment for AE will continue until the completion of the study, which is estimated to be an average of 1 year. How do you feel about including AE assessment as a primary outcome measure?

I'm glad you agree. Now let's move on to the secondary outcome measures. Based on the trial details, I suggest considering parameters related to the pharmacokinetics and efficacy of ND-003. These measures will provide valuable insights into the drug's absorption, distribution, elimination, and overall efficacy. What do you think?

Certainly! For the pharmacokinetic parameters, we can consider measuring the maximum concentration (Cmax) of ND-003, which reflects the drug's absorption rate and bioavailability. We can also assess the time to reach the maximum concentration (Tmax), which indicates the drug's onset of action. Additionally, we can measure the elimination half-life (t1/2) and clearance (CL/F) of ND-003, which provide information on the drug's elimination rate and systemic exposure. Assessments for these parameters will be conducted at various time points up to 72 hours after a single dose administration.

Yes, for the efficacy of ND-003, we can consider measuring the objective response rate (ORR), which assesses the tumor response to treatment based on RECIST criteria. This measure will provide insights into the drug's preliminary efficacy. We can also measure progression-free survival (PFS), which evaluates the time from randomization until objective tumor progression or death. Lastly, we can measure overall survival (OS), which assesses the overall survival of patients from randomization until death from any cause. These measures will help evaluate the drug's impact on disease progression and overall survival. Assessments for ORR, PFS, and OS will occur from baseline through up to 6 cycles or until disease progression.

I'm glad you find these measures valuable. To summarize, the full outcome measures for your clinical trial will be as follows:

Primary Outcome Measures:
1. Incidence of dose-limiting toxicity (DLT)
2. Maximum tolerated dose (MTD)
3. Adverse Events (AE) assessed by CTCAE ver5.0

Secondary Outcome Measures:
1. Maximum concentration (Cmax)
2. Time to maximum concentration (Tmax)
3. Elimination Half-life (t1/2)
4. Clearance (CL/F)
5. AUC from time 0 to last time of quantifiable concentration (AUC0-t)
6. Objective response rate (ORR)
7. Progression-free survival (PFS)
8. Overall survival (OS)

These outcome measures will provide valuable insights into the safety, pharmacokinetics, and efficacy of ND-003 in patients with advanced solid tumors.

Certainly! The Perceived Stress Scale (PSS) was developed by Cohen et al. (1983) and was designed to measure the amount of stress an individual experiences based on a specific period of time. The original PSS included 14 items, but in 1988, Cohen made minor revisions to the scale. The revised 10-item version has been found to have better psychometric properties than the original version (Cohen et al., 1994). The PSS has no subscales and includes 10 items rated on a 5-point scale. Answers are categorized as follows: “Never”, “Almost Never”, “Sometimes”, “Fairly Often”, and “Very Often”. The original version of the scale used these categories to score the items, which was transformed into a score between 0 and 40 in the revised version. We will administer the PSS at three different time points: before the implementation, eight weeks after the start of application, and six months after the start of application to assess the impact of the intervention on the perceived stress levels of the participants.

model_response: The WOMAC is a self-administered questionnaire that is filled by the participants. It was developed primarily for use in clinical studies related to osteoarthritis and has been validated for use in the knees and hips. It includes 24 questions, each addressing a specific symptom, such as pain or difficulty climbing stairs. The responses to the questions are graded on a Likert scale, which assigns a score of 0 to 10. The total score can range from 0 to 100, with a higher score indicating more pain, disability, or stiffness.

Assessments made using the WOMAC index typically focus on the last 48 hours, unless otherwise specified. This information would be important to capture in the measure description as well. Additionally, it is essential to specify if the time frame is a retrospective or prospective report of the symptoms. Furthermore, it would be helpful to consider adding a statement about the instrument's validity for use in knee osteoarthritis patients, especially if it has been tested in that specific population.

In addition to functional limitations, it would be beneficial to include pain and muscle strength as secondary outcome measures. This will allow for a more comprehensive evaluation of the effects of the interventions. I recommend using a pain scale for pain and a dynamometer for muscle strength. Would you like to continue with pain and/or muscle strength?

For pain intensity, the participant will be given a 10 cm Visual Analog Scale and asked to mark the line that indicates the intensity of their pain at rest and during the activity of quadriceps contraction. The measure will be marked on a scale of 0 (no pain) to 10 (the most intense pain). For muscle strength, the participant will be instructed to perform maximal voluntary isometric contractions (MVIC) for knee flexion and extension starting at a position of 30° of flexion. A handheld dynamometer will be placed over the front of the proximal tibia at the tibial tuberosity using an external moment arm calculated as 0.27 m (distance from the axis of rotation of the knee joint to the fixation point of the load cell). The participant will be asked to perform five repetitions of a five-second isometric contraction to achieve peak force. The measure will be represented in a unit of kilograms. Is it accurate?

For the secondary outcome measures, I recommend assessing pain intensity and muscle strength. Pain intensity can be measured using the Visual Analog Scale (VAS), which asks participants to mark their pain level on a 10 cm line. Muscle strength can be assessed using a handheld dynamometer, where participants perform maximal voluntary isometric contractions for knee flexion and extension. The force generated can then be measured in kilograms. Both measures can provide valuable insights into the effects of the interventions. What do you think?

What are your thoughts on these measures?

Certainly! Here are the Measure Descriptions and Time Frames for each of the suggested secondary outcome measures:

1. Invasive Disease-Free Survival (iDFS): "iDFS is defined as the time from the date of first dose of study treatment to the date of the first event of invasive ipsilateral breast tumor recurrence, local/regional invasive recurrence, distant recurrence, death (any cause), contralateral invasive BC, or second primary non-breast invasive cancer (excluding basal and squamous cell carcinomas of the skin)." This measure will be assessed using STEEP 2.0, as assessed by the investigator. The Time Frame for iDFS is up to approximately 6 years.

2. Distant Relapse-Free Survival (DRFS): "DRFS is defined as the time from the date of first dose of study treatment to the date of the first event of recurrence at a distant site or death (any cause)." This measure will be assessed using STEEP 2.0, as assessed by the investigator. The Time Frame for DRFS is up to approximately 6 years.

3. Recurrence-Free Interval (RFI): "RFI is defined as the time from date of first dose to date of first event of invasive recurrence in the ipsilateral breast or locoregionally, at a distant site, or death from breast cancer." This measure will be assessed using STEEP 2.0, as per investigator assessment. The Time Frame for RFI is up to approximately 6 years.

4. Relative dose intensity (RDI) of ribociclib: "RDI is defined as the ratio of the dose intensity delivered to the planned dose intensity." The Time Frame for assessing RDI is up to 3 years.

5. Overall Survival (OS): "OS is defined as time from the start of study treatment to date of death due to any cause." The Time Frame for assessing OS is up to approximately 6 years.

6. Time To Discontinuation (TTD) of ribociclib: "TTD is defined as the time from starting ribociclib to the time to treatment discontinuation due to any cause." The Time Frame for assessing TTD is up to 3 years.

7. Changes from baseline in Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Breast (FACT-B) score: "The FACT-B is a questionnaire that consists of 37 items with items from FACT-General (FACT-G) questionnaire (27 items) and from the Breast Cancer Subscale (BCS, 10 items). FACT-B consists of five subscales that address different aspects of the participant's quality of life: physical well-being (PWB), social/family well-being (SWB), emotional well-being (EWB), functional well-being (FWB), and BCS." The Time Frame for assessing changes in FACT-B score is up to approximately 6 years.

8. Changes from baseline in Functional Assessment of Cancer Therapy - Endocrine Symptoms (FACT-ES) score: "The FACT-ES is a questionnaire that consists of 19 items which assesses endocrine complaints and adverse events." The Time Frame for assessing changes in FACT-ES score is up to approximately 6 years.

9. Changes from baseline in Functional Assessment of Chronic Illness Therapy - Fatigue (FACIT-F) score: "The FACIT-F is a 13-item questionnaire designed to assess self-reported fatigue and its impact on daily activities and functions." The Time Frame for assessing changes in FACIT-F score is up to approximately 6 years.

10. Changes from baseline in European Quality of Life-5 Dimensions (EQ-5D-5L) score: "EQ-5D-5L is a standardized participant completed questionnaire that measures health-related quality of life and translates that score into an index value or utility score. EQ-5D-5L consists of two components: a health state profile and an optional visual analogue scale (VAS). EQ-5D-5L health state profile is comprised of 5 dimensions: mobility, self-care, usual activities, pain/discomfort and anxiety/depression." The Time Frame for assessing changes in EQ-5D-5L score is up to approximately 6 years.

11. Changes from baseline in Work Productivity and Activity Impairment Questionnaire (WPAI-GH) score: "WPAI-GH measures the impact of health problems on the participant's productivity, in paid or unpaid activities, in the last 7 days. It is a 6-item scale measuring absenteeism, presenteeism, and impairments in unpaid activity." The Time Frame for assessing changes in WPAI-GH score is up to approximately 6 years.

model_response: Another outcome measure that could be used is the occurrence of pulmonary embolism. The incidence of pulmonary embolism in the general population is about 30 per 100,000 person-years. In critically ill patients, the incidence of pulmonary embolism increases and can reach up to 65% in patients with burns. The diagnosis of pulmonary embolism can be made using computed tomography, magnetic resonance imaging, ultrasonography, or pulmonary angiography. However, it is important to note that these methods have varying sensitivities and specificities. If an accurate diagnosis of pulmonary embolism can be made within a reasonable time frame, this can be used as the outcome measure. The current study design is set up to measure changes in the outcome measure several times within the same subject. To assess the variance of the changes at different time points, you can perform a repeated measure analysis. The repeated measure analysis is a statistical technique that takes into account the correlation between repeated measures of the same subjects. This allows you to incorporate the repeated measure information into the statistical model and obtain an unbiased estimate of the variance of the changes within subjects. However, it is important to consider the effect of repeated measurements on subjects before performing the analysis. The effect of repeated measures can be increased if subjects are not allowed to "wash out" between repeated measurements; this is known as a carryover effect. To address this issue, it is recommended to establish a washout period between repeated measures. In your study, each subject will undergo four sampling time points, which is considered a sufficient number of repeated measures to determine the variance of changes within subjects. It would be beneficial to incorporate your plan for a follow-up study at subsequent time points in your study design. In this case, you can collect samples from a subset of subjects at subsequent time points. This will provide you with additional data to analyze the variance of changes within subjects and will also allow you to establish a future follow-up study design.
