Here's a description of the primary outcome measure, as well as the suggested time frame for using it:Static Component of the Berg Balance Scale (BBS)The Static Component of the Berg Balance Scale is a 14-item instrument that assesses an individual's balance when standing or sitting. Each item is scored on a scale from 0 (unable to complete) to 4 (able to complete independently and safely). The total score ranges from 0 to 56, with a higher score indicating better balance. The BBS has demonstrated excellent test-retest reliability (ICC = 0.98) and good content and construct validity in the stroke population.The BBS should be conducted over a period of about 30 to 45 min, including the explanations of the test, testing procedures, and administration of the test. The BBS should be performed twice, with at least 5 min between attempts to minimize practice effects.The PoData Stabiliometric PlateThe PoData Stabiliometric Plate is a sensor-based system that assesses an individual's standing balance while on a firm surface. PoData Stabiliometric Plates are commonly used in research to collect balance data and have been validated in many studies. The system measures plantar pressure distribution, center of pressure, and other variables that indicate an individual's ability to maintain their balance while standing still.The PoData Stabiliometric Plate should be used at two assessment time points: at baseline (A1) and after 8 weeks of treatment (A2). The PoData Stabiliometric Plate should be conducted over a period of 2 to 5 min, including the setup, instructions and actual measurements. The system is capable of assessing dynamic sway with a high sample rate (100 Hz) and should be used at both visits.The data collected from the PoData Stabiliometric Plate system should be scored using specialized software provided by PoData LLC.

For assessing the secondary factors, I suggest including: a) a questionnaire on subjective postural and kinesthetic awareness and b) the Timed Up and Go test. The questionnaire on subjective postural and kinesthetic awareness can directly evaluate the subjective level of postural and kinesthetic awareness in patients. The Timed Up and Go test is a clinical test to assess balance and lower limb function. As for this measure, the time required for patients to perform the test will be assessed and analyzed.

Certainly! The Modified Ashworth Scale is a widely used tool for measuring spasticity. It is measured using a scale from 0 to 4, with 0 indicating no increase in tone; 1+ indicating a slight increase in tone, giving a catch and release when the affected part of the limb is moved; 1-+ indicating a slight increase in tone, the affected part of the limb moving only when the examiner forces the limb to move slowly; 2 indicating stiffness and some limit to passive movement, with free passive movement only in the direction of motion required, while 3 indicating a marked increase in tone, stiffening the whole limb, and giving some resistance to passive movement even when the examiner is moving the limb slowly in the direction of motion required. The Modified Ashworth Scale will be assessed at both the 0, 6, and 12-month mark.

Primary Outcome Measure:
- Pathologic complete response (PCR) rate: Assessing the proportion of participants who have achieved a complete pathological response with no tumor cells found in the tumor bed or lymph nodes. The time frame for assessment is up to 30 months.

Secondary Outcome Measures:
- Objective response rate (ORR): Defined according to the RECIST v1.1 criteria.
- Major pathologic response (MPR) rate: Assessing the proportion of participants with tumors containing no more than 10% viable tumor cells using routine hematoxylin and eosin staining.
- Treatment-related adverse event (TRAE): Defined and classified according to the NCI-CTCAE v5.0 criteria.
- Event-free survival (EFS): Measuring the time from randomization to disease progression, recurrence, or death.
- Overall survival (OS): Measuring the time from enrollment to death due to any cause.
- EORTC-QLQ-C30 scale: Assessing the quality of life using a validated scale designed for lung cancer patients.
